questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain and swelling in her right knee for 3 days. She underwent a total knee arthroplasty of her right knee joint 5 months ago. The procedure and immediate aftermath were uneventful. She has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), pulse is 95/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen right knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Arthrocentesis of the right knee is performed. Analysis of the synovial fluid shows:


Appearance
Cloudy


Viscosity
Absent


WBC count
78,000/mm3



Segmented neutrophils
94%


Lymphocytes
6%


Synovial fluid is sent for culture and antibiotic sensitivity. Which of the following is the most likely causal pathogen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is found in immunosuppressed patients with arthritis. The patient has no history of conditions that would predispose her to P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., underlying malignancy, IV drug use, diabetes mellitus), which makes this pathogen an unlikely cause.

B) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis has the ability to form a biofilm and can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. This patient underwent an arthroplasty in her right knee 5 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 months after surgery. If this patient had presented within < 3 months after the arthroplasty or > 12 months after surgery, Staphylococcus aureus would be most likely. Treatment of prosthetic joint infections usually consists of removal of the prosthesis and debridement of the bone and surrounding tissue, followed by IV antibiotics (e.g., oxacillin or ceftriaxone) for 6–8 weeks. Reimplantation of the prosthesis should be performed after repeat negative synovial fluid cultures or after completion of antimicrobial therapy if clinical signs of infection are absent.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, patients with joint infection due to S. aureus are usually acutely ill with high fever, chills, and present within 3 months after arthroplasty. Given the fact that this patient presents 5 months after surgery, an infection with a less virulent pathogen is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a possible cause of septic arthritis in immunosuppressed patients. However, the patient has no history of immunosuppression, this pathogen an unlikely cause.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae (or group B Streptococcus) does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this pathogen an unlikely cause.
questions.hint: A painful swollen knee, restricted range of motion, low-grade fever, and synovial fluid analysis showing purulent synovial fluid and increased WBC count with neutrophil predominance are suggestive of infectious arthritis. This patient's history of arthroplasty makes a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of fever and pain in the left lower extremity. His mother says that he has refused to walk for the past two days and has had a poor appetite. He returned from a weekend camping trip about a month ago. His maternal cousin died of osteosarcoma at the age of 12. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 80th percentile for height and 70th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 95/50 mm Hg. Examination of the left hip shows tenderness; range of motion is limited. Minimal attempts to rotate the hip cause severe discomfort. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12 g/dL


Leukocyte count
19,800/mm3


Platelet count
254,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
55 mm/h


Serum



 Glucose
80 mg/dL


 C-reactive peptide

15 mg/L


X-rays of the pelvis shows a widened acetabular space on the left side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Synovial fluid drainage and cefazolin therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bed rest and acetaminophen are used to treat transient synovitis, a temporary inflammation of the hip joint common in children that is often preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection. Transient synovitis manifests with pain in the groin, hip, and/or knee, as well as a decreased range of motion in the hip because of pain, which is seen in this patient. However, the laboratory and imaging findings in this patient are more consistent with septic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin would be part of the empiric treatment for septic arthritis if this patient had a history of recent hospitalization or lived in an area with high MRSA prevalence, which is not the case here (MRSA prevalence is approx. 2% in the US). In addition, rapid reduction of both bacterial activity and pressure within the infected joint are important if long-term complications are to be avoided, and antibiotic therapy solely targets bacterial activity.

C) CORRECT:

If septic arthritis is suspected, prompt synovial fluid drainage should be conducted (via arthrocentesis), followed by empiric antibiotic therapy to minimize the risk of long-term joint complications. Drained synovial fluid should be sent for Gram stain, culture, and susceptibility testing, and antibiotics should be tailored to the results when they become available. Initial antibiotic therapy should cover Staphylococcus aureus, the most common cause of septic arthritis. Patients are often given vancomycin if they have a high risk of MRSA infection and/or signs of sepsis are present. However, an appropriate antibiotic for this child, who has no history of hospitalization and therefore is unlikely to have an MRSA infection, would be parenteral cefazolin (see “Empiric antibiotic therapy for pediatric patients with septic arthritis of native joints” table).

D) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the hip provides high-resolution images that are particularly useful in investigating soft tissue pathologies or if the diagnosis is unclear. However, the clinical picture in this patient is clear enough to warrant prompt initiation of therapy for septic arthritis. MRI can be used later in septic arthritis to examine possible infectious involvement of the surrounding soft tissue. However, obtaining an MRI can be time-consuming, especially as a 2-year-old would require sedation, and is therefore not an appropriate first step.

E) INCORRECT:

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is commonly prescribed for urinary tract infections caused by E. coli and other gram-negative bacteria, as well as prophylaxis for opportunistic infections in HIV/AIDS patients. It is not commonly used in septic arthritis, which requires an antibiotic with gram-positive coverage that includes S. aureus.

F) INCORRECT:

Arthroscopy may be used for septic arthritis if the infection is located in a joint that is difficult to aspirate, such as the hip. However, arthroscopic drainage would only allow for joint decompression in this patient and would not treat the underlying infection, which should also be addressed to avoid long-term complications. Moreover, a less invasive approach should be considered in this child.

G) INCORRECT:

A bone biopsy would be indicated if imaging studies showed radiographic signs of malignancy (e.g., periosteal reactions such as a sunburst appearance or Codman triangle). However, the widened acetabular space seen on this patient's x-ray indicates excess fluid (e.g., an abscess) rather than malignancy. Since his presentation and labwork already indicate septic arthritis, a bone biopsy would not aid diagnosis or treatment.

H) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for Lyme disease and can be used in children < 8 years of age for short durations (i.e., ≤ 21 days). Although Lyme arthritis may manifest with hip pain in disseminated disease and this patient's camping trip is a risk factor for tick bites, his acute presentation, high fever, and imaging findings are not consistent with this condition.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, elevated inflammatory markers (leukocyte count, ESR, CRP), and x-ray findings indicate septic arthritis of the hip (i.e., bacterial coxitis).

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of right knee pain for the past 3 days. During this period, the girl has refused to walk. Her mother reports that her symptoms began after she fell down while playing. Three weeks ago, the patient had a sore throat and was treated with penicillin V. Her father has hemophilia A and has had repeated episodes of joint pain and swelling following minor injury. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 21/min. The right knee joint is warm and erythematous. The girl starts to cry as soon as the physician tries to flex the knee joint. Further evaluation of this patient is likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A prolonged PTT (measures activity of factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII) is seen in hemophilia A and hemophilia B. This patient's father has a history consistent with hemophilia, which manifests with bleeding out of proportion to the inciting event. In cases of joint trauma, hemarthrosis is common. Spontaneous hemarthrosis can also occur. Warmth and pain over this patient's knee could indicate bleeding into the joint space, but would not explain her fever. Most importantly, these conditions are X-linked recessive, meaning that female patients are generally only potential carriers of the genetic defect.

B) INCORRECT:

Needle-shaped crystals (composed of uric acid) in the synovial fluid are diagnostic for gout. Gout typically affects older adults, sometimes after an inciting event such as heavy alcohol or red meat consumption. A history of previous attacks is usually present. Attacks often affect a single joint (classically podagra) and involve acute, excruciating pain, redness, warmth, and swelling. The patient described here is much younger than most patients with gout, and the disease course is too long (3 days vs. a few hours).
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

C) INCORRECT:

A positive antinuclear antibody test would be helpful in diagnosing pediatric rheumatological conditions, especially juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although each rheumatological condition has its own unique diagnostic criteria, the joint manifestations are similar: chronic symptoms, oligoarticular distribution, and stiffness/pain that improves with activity. Systemic manifestations (e.g., fevers that spike twice a day in JIA) and multiorgan involvement (most notably of the skin) are also typical. This patient's symptoms are acute, monoarticular, and there is no other extraarticular organ involvement, so a rheumatological condition is unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Transverse patellar fractures are extremely rare in the pediatric population because of the relative flexibility of the incompletely ossified patella. A patellar sleeve fracture would be more common in children. In either case, the examination would demonstrate a displaced patella, exquisite tenderness, and evidence of hemarthrosis. It would not explain this patient's fever.

E) CORRECT:

Gram-positive cocci in the synovial fluid indicate septic arthritis, probably caused by Staphylococcus (S. aureus is most common in the US) or Streptococcus species. Upper respiratory tract infection (e.g., sore throat) predisposes to bacteremia and often precedes septic arthritis. The combination of acute severe joint pain, warmth, erythema, and fever is highly concerning for septic arthritis, which requires rapid management to avoid severe joint destruction and systemic infection. Synovial fluid aspiration should be performed emergently to both relieve pressure in the joint and for laboratory analysis. Findings of a WBC count > 50,000/mL, polymorphonuclear cell predominance, low synovial glucose (< 30% serum glucose), and Gram stain results all support the diagnosis. Empiric treatment with an anti-staphylococcal parenteral antibiotic (e.g., cefazolin) should be administered immediately.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

F) INCORRECT:

Common causes of prolonged PT (measures the clotting ability of factors I, II, V, VII, and X) include warfarin use, vitamin K deficiency, and chronic liver disease, which may be associated with spontaneous bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis). Warmth and pain over the affected joint could indicate bleeding into the joint space, but this patient has no risk factors for such conditions and hemarthrosis would not explain her fever.

G) INCORRECT:

A new systolic heart murmur may indicate mitral regurgitation, which is the most common valvular lesion in acute rheumatic fever (RF). RF typically occurs within 1–5 weeks of group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection and can manifest with fever and signs of arthritis (joint pain, warmth, erythema, limited range of motion). However, this patient's pharyngitis was treated with penicillin V, which makes RF unlikely. Moreover, arthritis associated with RF is usually polyarticular and migratory.

H) INCORRECT:

Gram-negative bacilli in the synovial fluid would be concerning for septic arthritis. In the past, infections with gram-negative bacilli (particularly Haemophilus influenzae) were very common, especially in children. Since the introduction of the HiB vaccine, infection with this bacterial species has become much less common. Though other gram-negative bacilli are known to cause septic arthritis (notably Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Escherichia coli), they are associated with specific risk factors such as injection drug use or recent surgery. This patient has no identifiable risk factors and has been vaccinated, making joint infection by gram-negative bacilli much less likely.

I) INCORRECT:

Rhomboid crystals in the synovial fluid would be a sign of pseudogout, which would manifest with symptoms similar to gout: paroxysmal episodes of pain, joint swelling, warmth, and redness. Symptoms are classically not systemic, but a low-grade fever is possible. While the clinical features of pseudogout may be similar to those described here, pseudogout is almost always seen in older adults. It would be extremely unlikely for an otherwise healthy 6-year-old girl to present with pseudogout.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.
questions.hint: The synovial fluid in this patient will be turbid and have increased protein levels.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive pain and swelling of his left knee for the past 2 days. He has been taking ibuprofen for the past 2 days without improvement. Four days ago, he scraped his left knee while playing baseball. He has a 2-month history of progressive pain and stiffness in his back. The pain starts after waking up and lasts for 20 minutes. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His older sister has rheumatoid arthritis. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 91 kg (201 lb); BMI is 31.5 kg/m2. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows an erythematous, tender, and swollen left knee; range of motion is limited. There are abrasions over the lateral aspect of the left knee. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,500/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 70 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bone scan can be used to detect or exclude polyarticular involvement in a patient with suspected septic arthritis. However, while this aids diagnosis by showing effusion or evidence of inflammation, it is not confirmatory.
Image Description:

Scintigraphy: increased radionuclide activity in the left shoulder joint
Diagnosis: septic arthritis of the shoulder

B) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular glucocorticoid injections are commonly used for osteoarthritis and occasionally for rheumatoid flares. However, since intraarticular glucocorticoid injections are immunosuppressive, they would be absolutely contraindicated in this patient, given the cause of his symptoms is potentially infectious.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI is rarely part of the initial workup of an acutely inflamed joint, as it would not provide a specific diagnosis that would guide therapy in most cases. Instead, MRI is used to assess for complications of septic arthritis (e.g., periarticular abscess, osteomyelitis) after a diagnosis is established and treatment is begun. MRI may be part of the early workup in patients with sacroiliac or sternoclavicular arthritis to assess for spread of infection into the pelvis or mediastinum, respectively.
Image Description:

MRI Hips (axial view; T1 weighted; with contrast) of an 11-year-old boy with a painful left hip and a fever.

The synovium of the left hip is thickened and there is a joint effusion. As this is a T1-weighted image, fluid appears hypointense and therefore the effusion demonstrates hypointense signal (blue overlay). The synovium of the hip demonstrates hyperintense signal due to enhancement (green overlay). A large area of soft tissue around the left hip enhances, demonstrated as hyperintense signal around the hip joint (red overlay). This is due to inflammation of these soft tissues.

The main differentials for these imaging findings are septic arthritis and transient synovitis. It is often very difficult to differentiate these two conditions on imaging alone during the early stages. Bone marrow edema in the femur or acetabulum, or extensive soft tissue edema around the joint is more suggestive of septic arthritis but is not always demonstrated early, and aspiration of joint fluid may be required to aid diagnosis. This is an example of septic arthritis.

Outlines: Sartorius m., Rectus femoris m., Tensor fasciae latae m.

D) INCORRECT:

X-ray of the knee is a reasonable first test to assess for osteomyelitis, which is a potential complication of septic arthritis. However, knee x-ray would not provide specific diagnostic data regarding the cause of this patient's arthritis. This patient requires emergent testing to diagnose and likely treat his arthritis before x-ray would be indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Two sets of blood cultures should be drawn prior to starting antibiotics for suspected septic arthritis since it is most commonly caused by hematogenous seeding of the joint. Blood cultures are positive in 50% of cases of septic arthritis. Although this patient should have blood cultures drawn, results take hours to days, and septic arthritis is an emergency that requires another test to more immediately guide therapy.

F) CORRECT:

Arthrocentesis should be performed immediately if septic arthritis is part of the differential diagnosis (e.g., acute joint pain, redness, swelling). If untreated, septic arthritis rapidly causes severe joint damage, primarily through bacterial invasion of cartilage. Therefore, ruling out or starting treatment for septic arthritis is imperative. This patient has risk factors for a number of causes of acute arthritis, including type 2 diabetes mellitus and local trauma (septic arthritis), reactive arthritis (possible HLA-B27 positivity given potentially undiagnosed ankylosing spondylitis), and crystalline arthritis (middle-aged male with type 2 DM and obesity). Synovial fluid analysis can reliably distinguish these differential diagnoses.

If synovial fluid analysis shows a markedly elevated WBC count (usually > 50,000 cells/mm3) with a neutrophilic shift and no crystals are seen, empiric antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis should be instituted immediately, even if the Gram stain is negative (sensitivity is ∼ 75% for septic arthritis). The most common source of septic arthritis is hematogenous spread, followed by direct spread of infection.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

G) INCORRECT:

Serologic testing may detect some causes of acute arthritis (e.g., Lyme disease, HLA-B27 positivity, rheumatoid factor). However, these tests would not change acute management, so they are not part of the initial workup of an acutely inflamed joint. These tests may be considered once emergent causes of symptoms have been ruled out or empiric treatment has been established.

H) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs are commonly recommended for osteoarthritis, joint sprains, or bursitis, all of which can present with acute knee pain and swelling. However, none of these conditions present with systemic signs of infection (fever, leukocytosis).
questions.hint: This patient has a history of diabetes mellitus and a swollen, erythematous, and tender knee associated with fever and leukocytosis, which is highly suggestive of septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman comes to the physician because of right knee pain and difficulty bearing weight on the right leg for 5 days. She underwent right total knee replacement 8 weeks ago. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Her hemoglobin A1c was 8.5% 2 months ago. Her mother died of rheumatoid arthritis complicated by interstitial lung disease. The patient's current medications include metformin, lisinopril, and aspirin. She is 157 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 148/108 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a right knee scar with an erythematous border. There is no drainage. Range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness to palpation over the right knee joint. She has an antalgic gait. Analysis of joint fluid aspirate is most likely to show which of the following?



Appearance
WBC (PMN %)
Glucose (mg/dL)
Culture
Crystals



A
Opaque
35,000 (90)
15
gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci
none


B
Red
1,000 (50)
90
negative
none


C
Opaque
20,000 (60)
25
negative
monosodium urate


D
Transparent
550 (22)
85
negative
calcium phosphate


E
Transparent
50 (16)
85
negative
none


F
Opaque
5,000 (70)
40
gram-positive, coagulase-negative cocci
none


G
Opaque
20,000 (60)
25
negative
calcium pyrophosphate
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In early-onset PJI, synovial fluid analysis often shows opaque joint fluid (due to the buildup of dead leukocytes), increased WBC count (> 1100/mm3), and PMN dominance. Furthermore, cultures are usually positive, glucose levels are much lower than serum levels due to the glycolytic activity of bacteria, and crystals are not present. The most common organism responsible for early-onset PJI is S. aureus (gram-positive, coagulase-positive cocci). Late-onset PJI (> 12 months of placement) typically develops due to hematogenous spread from a satellite infection and is also most commonly associated with S. aureus.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

B) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid with a reddish appearance, 200–2000 WBCs/μL, negative culture, normal glucose levels, and a lack of crystals is indicative of hemarthrosis. Hemarthrosis may be due to trauma, especially in hemophilic patients. It rarely occurs after surgery; if it does, however, symptoms manifest hours to days after the procedure. The onset of monoarticular joint pain 8 weeks after surgery that is seen in this patient is not suggestive of hemarthrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A synovial fluid analysis showing elevated WBCs/μL, negative culture, low glucose levels, and negatively birefringent needle-shaped monosodium urate crystals is characteristic of gout. Although an acute gout flare may manifest with severe pain, redness, swelling, and disability of the affected joint, symptoms usually reach their maximum severity within 12–24 hours. Complete resolution of an attack usually occurs within a few days.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

D) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid with a transparent appearance, mildly elevated WBCs/μL, normal percentage of PMNs, negative culture, and normal glucose is suggestive of a noninflammatory arthritis such as osteoarthritis. In 60% of cases of osteoarthritis, calcium phosphate crystals are present. Although osteoarthritis may manifest with joint pain and limited range of motion, it usually affects multiple joints. Furthermore, it is not typically associated with inflammatory symptoms such as redness and erythema.

E) INCORRECT:

This is a normal synovial fluid analysis. This patient, who has inflammatory and infectious symptoms, would most likely have abnormal findings on synovial fluid analysis.

F) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid with a WBC count of over 1100/mm3, a PMN distribution of over 64%, positive culture, low glucose, and absence of crystals is consistent with PJI. The culture result of gram-positive, coagulase-negative cocci likely indicates infection with Staphylococcus epidermidis, which may cause infections of prosthetic devices due to its propensity to form biofilms. However, PJI caused by S. epidermidis tends to be delayed in onset (occurring between 3–12 months of placement).

G) INCORRECT:

Synovial fluid with elevated WBCs/μL, elevated PMNs, negative culture, low glucose levels, and rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals are characteristic of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystal deposition disease (pseudogout). Although pseudogout may manifest in older patients with sudden-onset monoarticular and inflammatory joint pain, attacks are limited to a few days and are usually provoked by trauma, surgery, or severe medical illness. This patient's symptoms are not self-limited and began after a surgical procedure, making pseudogout an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals with typical rhomboid shapes. They appear blue when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer and yellow when their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer (positive birefringence). The overall birefringence of CPP crystals is weak compared to monosodium urate crystals.
questions.hint: This patient has fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion of the affected joint, constituting the classic triad of septic arthritis. Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus and a recent history of right total knee replacement are risk factors for this condition. Monoarticular joint pain appearing < 3 months after surgery with erythema limited to the right knee incision site suggests an early-onset prosthetic joint infection (PJI).

questions.text: An 82-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe pain and joint stiffness in his right knee. The pain started 3 days ago and has worsened despite acetaminophen intake. He has benign prostatic hyperplasia and hypertension. One week ago, he had a urinary tract infection and was treated with nitrofurantoin. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His current medications include enalapril, hydrochlorothiazide, and tamsulosin. He appears to be in severe pain and has trouble moving his right knee. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.5°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a swollen, erythematous, warm right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. Synovial fluid aspiration shows a yellow-green turbid fluid. Gram stain of the synovial aspirate shows numerous leukocytes and multiple gram-negative rods. An x-ray of the right knee shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IV nafcillin or other penicillins (e.g., oxacillin, flucloxacillin) may be used for empirical treatment of septic arthritis caused by gram-positive cocci, provided the likelihood of MRSA infection is low. Nafcillin would not be effective against the gram-negative rods causing this patient's arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

IV vancomycin with either ceftazidime or an aminoglycoside is a broad-spectrum regimen that covers gram-positive as well as gram-negative organisms. This regimen is the preferred empirical treatment of septic arthritis if the Gram stain does not show any organisms. It would not be the most appropriate combination of antibiotics in this patient whose Gram stain shows gram-negative bacilli.

C) CORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is based on the Gram stain of the synovial fluid of the affected joint and should be initiated as early as possible to minimize the risk of sepsis and damage to the affected joint. In this case, the Gram stain shows gram-negative bacilli, which, given the history of a preceding urinary tract infection, is most likely to be Escherichia coli. The empiric antibiotics of choice for gram-negative bacilli are third-generation cephalosporins (e.g., ceftazidime) or fourth-generation cephalosporins (e.g., cefepime). Alternative empiric antibiotics for gram-negative bacilli include piperacillin/tazobactam, carbapenems, and, in patients with a known allergy to beta-lactam antibiotics, fluoroquinolones or aztreonam.

D) INCORRECT:

A combination of ceftazidime and an aminoglycoside (gentamicin) is an empiric antibiotic regimen in patients with suspected Pseudomonas aeruginosa septic arthritis. Pseudomonas is a gram-negative rod (GNR). However, this patient has no risk factors for Pseudomonas infection, such as IV drug use, diabetes mellitus, or recent nosocomial infection. Moreover, this patient's recent UTI suggests another GNR is the likely cause of his septic arthritis. Finally, gentamicin, a nephrotoxic drug, should be used sparingly in older individuals.

E) INCORRECT:

IV vancomycin is preferred in septic arthritis caused by gram-positive cocci if the risk of MRSA infection is high, e.g., in patients with prolonged hospitalization, indwelling catheters, living in nursing homes, immunosuppression, and recent use of antibiotics. Although this patient has recently used antibiotics and may have a weakened immune system due to his advanced age, the Gram stain of his synovial fluid shows gram-negative bacilli. Vancomycin is not effective against gram-negative rods.
questions.hint: This patient presents with severe pain and joint stiffness one week after a urinary tract infection. Together with yellow-green turbid fluid on synovial fluid analysis, these features suggest septic arthritis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening severe pain, swelling, and stiffness in her right knee for the past 2 days. She recently started running 2 miles, 3 times a week in an attempt to lose weight. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteoporosis. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily. She is sexually active with multiple partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Current medications include metformin and alendronate. She is 161 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 74 kg (163 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 115/76 mm Hg. She appears to be in discomfort and has trouble putting weight on the affected knee. Physical examination shows a 2-cm, painless ulcer on the plantar surface of the right toe. The right knee is swollen and tender to palpation. Arthrocentesis of the right knee with synovial fluid analysis shows a cell count of 55,000 WBC/μL with 77% polymorphonuclear (PMN) cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's presenting condition?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the tibial tuberosity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis, which is the likely diagnosis in this patient, can be caused by direct inoculation of bacteria secondary to iatrogenic interventions (e.g., arthrocentesis, arthroscopy) or trauma (e.g., open wounds around the joint, penetrating trauma). However, this patient has no history of recent joint procedure or trauma and physical examination did not show open wounds around the knee, making a different etiology more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

This is the mechanism of reactive arthritis, which usually manifests with fever, malaise, and lower extremity joint pain. This patient's inconsistent use of condoms puts her at risk for infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, which can cause reactive arthritis. However, reactive arthritis typically manifests as asymmetrical polyarthritis, which is often combined with sacroiliitis and extra‑articular symptoms (e.g., conjunctivitis or anterior uveitis). Moreover, while synovial fluid analysis in a patient with autoimmune-mediated inflammation may also show increased total WBC, dominance of PMN would likely be less pronounced. Furthermore, this patient lacks symptoms of a preceding infection such as diarrhea or dysuria, making a different diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Occult meniscal tears can arise from knee injuries or degenerative processes. Although there is no history of recent knee trauma, this patient recently started exercising and she could have suffered a previously undiagnosed meniscal tear. However, injury would typically cause a much lower overall WBC and PMN on synovial fluid analysis. Moreover, some cases of injury can lead to blood in the synovial fluid (hemarthrosis), which this patient does not have.

D) CORRECT:

This patient presents with typical symptoms of septic arthritis, including fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion. The knee is a commonly affected joint in septic arthritis, which is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site, such as an infected diabetic ulcer. Other characteristics of septic arthritis include a synovial fluid WBC count > 50,000/μL and polymorphonuclear cell predominance, as seen here. Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric treatment for septic arthritis (parenteral antibiotics based on the Gram stain) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage, which is primarily caused by bacterial invasion of cartilage.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

E) INCORRECT:

Avascular necrosis of the tibial tuberosity causes Osgood-Schlatter disease, which manifests with anterior knee pain worsened by activity and proximal tibial swelling. However, this diagnosis is not associated with fever, joint stiffness, or limited range of motion, and occurs mostly in boys 9–14 years of age. Lastly, Osgood-Schlatter disease would manifest with a low total WBC and PMN count, unlike the findings on this patient's synovial fluid analysis.
Image Description:

X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the knee

The fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

F) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular deposition of urate crystals causes arthritic symptoms in patients with gout. This patient's regular alcohol consumption, weight, and diabetes mellitus put her at increased risk for gout. She also has some typical findings of an acute gout attack such as joint pain, swelling, restricted range of motion, an elevated WBC, and low glucose levels on synovial fluid analysis. While this patient's symptoms are very similar to acute gout, the absence of monosodium urate crystals on synovial fluid analysis and the presence of a diabetic foot ulcer suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient is currently being treated with metformin and alendronate. While metformin is not commonly associated with musculoskeletal side effects, bisphosphonates like alendronate may cause bone and joint pain. However, fever and acute monoarthritis, along with the findings on synovial fluid analysis suggest a different diagnosis.

H) INCORRECT:

An autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the synovium causes joint destruction in rheumatoid arthritis (RA). This patient's family history puts her at an increased risk for RA, which may also affect the knee joints. However, it would typically manifest with symmetrical polyarthritis of the finger and wrist joints, morning stiffness, and constitutional symptoms, which this patient does not have. The dramatically increased total WBC and dominance of PMN are more suggestive of a different condition.
Image Description:

Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.
questions.hint: Permanent joint destruction is a dreaded complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in her left knee. To lose weight, she recently started jogging for 30 minutes a few times per week. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with metformin and chlorothiazide. Her sister has rheumatoid arthritis. She is sexually active with two partners and uses condoms inconsistently. On examination, her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 138/87 mm Hg. The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation with a significantly impaired range of motion. A 1.5-cm, painless ulcer is seen on the plantar surface of the left foot. Which of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of occult meniscal tears, which can arise from knee injuries or degenerative processes. Although there is no history of recent knee trauma, this patient recently started exercising and she could have suffered a previously undiagnosed meniscal tear. However, meniscal tears cannot explain this patient's fever, and in the presence of a distant wound site, another diagnosis would be more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is the best next step in this patient with typical symptoms of septic arthritis, including fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion. The knee is a commonly affected joint in septic arthritis, which is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site, such as an infected diabetic ulcer. Typical findings in arthrocentesis include a synovial fluid WBC count of over 50,000/μL with dominance of polymorphonuclear cells (PMN).

Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric treatment for septic arthritis (parenteral antibiotics based on the Gram stain) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage, which is primarily caused by bacterial invasion of cartilage.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

C) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 can aid in the diagnosis of reactive arthritis, which usually presents with fever, malaise, and lower extremity joint pain. This patient's inconsistent use of condoms puts her at risk for infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, which can cause reactive arthritis. However, it typically presents as asymmetrical polyarthritis that is often combined with sacroiliitis and extra‑articular symptoms (e.g., conjunctivitis or anterior uveitis), which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this patient lacks symptoms of a preceding infection such as diarrhea or dysuria.
Image Description:

Soles of an adult patient with reactive arthritis

Multiple hyperpigmented papules and plaques are visible on the soles of the forefoot.
The glabrous skin of the forefoot appears thickened and scaly (hyperkeratosis).

This is the typical manifestation of keratoderma blenorrhagicum, a cutaneous eruption seen in a third of patients with reactive arthritis (Reiter syndrome).

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor test can aid in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). This patient's family history puts her at an increased risk for RA, which may also affect the knee joints. However, it would typically present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the finger and wrist joints, morning stiffness, and constitutional symptoms, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Ultrasonography of the knee can aid in the diagnosis of Osgood-Schlatter disease, which presents with anterior knee pain worsened by activities such as running and jumping. However, this diagnosis is not associated with fever, or limited range of motion, and occurs mostly in boys 9–14 years of age.

F) INCORRECT:

Serum uric acid levels can be elevated in patients with gout. This patient's use of thiazide diuretics, weight, and diabetes mellitus put her at increased risk for gout. She also has some typical findings of an acute gout attack such as joint pain, swelling, and restricted range of motion. However, the presence of a distant wound site makes another diagnosis more likely. Furthermore, serum uric acid levels can be normal, raised, or even low during an acute gouty attack. Therefore, measuring serum uric acid levels may not be useful in diagnosis.
Image Description:

Sample of synovial fluid under polarizing light microscopy

Monosodium urate crystals are needle-shaped and appear yellow when their optical axis is oriented parallel to the polarizer. If their axis is perpendicular to the polarizer, they appear blue. The underlying physical principle is called negative birefringence.

Detection of negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid confirms the diagnosis of gout.
questions.hint: Permanent joint destruction is a dreaded complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of excruciating left knee pain for 4 days. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty of his left knee joint 4 months ago. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen left knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. Analysis of the synovial fluid confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis has the ability to form a biofilm. It can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. The patient underwent an arthroplasty in his left knee 4 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 months after surgery.

If the patient's infection had developed either < 3 months or > 12 months after surgery, Staphylococcus aureus would be the most likely causal organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a possible cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. However, this patient has no history of immunodeficiency, making this answer unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, patients with joint infection due to S. aureus are usually acutely ill with high fever, chills, and onset of symptoms within 3 months after arthroplasty (when the infection is acquired during implantation) or after 12 months from surgery (due to hematogenous infection). Given the fact that this patient presents 4 months after surgery, an infection with a less virulent pathogen is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. This patient has no history of conditions that would increase the risk of P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., malignancy, HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), which makes this answer unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae, a group B Streptococcus, does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this answer unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with a tender and swollen knee and low-grade fever is consistent with septic arthritis. His history of arthroplasty makes a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely, even 4 months after the operation.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening pain in her right hip and thigh. During this time, she has also had fever, fatigue, and malaise. Her father says she has been limping for the past 2 days and woke up several times the night before because of pain. She does not remember any trauma. She is on a soccer team but missed the last training due to a cold. She has a history of psoriasis treated with topical steroids. Her mother has psoriatic arthritis. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears ill. She is at the 50th percentile for height and the 90th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 95/57 mm Hg. She holds her right leg in a flexed, abducted, and externally rotated position during the examination. The area over the right hip joint is warm to the touch and reddened. The right hip and thigh are tender to palpation and attempts to passively or actively move the upper leg cause severe discomfort. There are numerous well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling over both elbows. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Direct inoculation of a pathogen into the hip joint cavity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Hematogenous spread of infection to the hip joint
Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the hip joint synovium
Insufficient blood supply to the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis of the hip can be caused by direct inoculation of bacteria secondary to iatrogenic interventions (e.g., arthrocentesis, arthroscopy) or trauma (e.g., open wounds around the joint, penetrating trauma). However, this patient has no history of recent joint procedure or trauma, and physical examination did not show open wounds around the hip joint, so a different etiology is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck (i.e., slipped capital femoral epiphysis, SCFE) can cause acute onset severe hip pain, limping, and restricted movement of the affected hip, which this patient has. Moreover, SCFE is more common in obese children, like this patient. However, affected children are typically > 10 years of age. Moreover, this patient is holding her hip abducted for pain relief, whereas in SCFE abduction is reduced and painful. Finally, fever and local warmth and erythema are not expected in patients with SCFE.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with characteristic symptoms of septic arthritis of the hip (bacterial coxitis), including fever, joint pain, restricted range of motion, local erythema and warmth, and typical hip position (i.e., flexed, abducted, externally rotated). This condition is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site or due to a recent upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection. Bacterial coxitis is a rare condition and an orthopedic emergency that requires prompt arthrocentesis and culture for diagnosis. Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric broad spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis (e.g., vancomycin, cefazolin) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage. Additionally, drainage with debridement of necrotic tissue and lavage should be performed to decompress the joint; the hip joint is usually approached via open surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the hip joint synovium can be seen in patients with juvenile psoriatic arthritis (psoriatic JIA). Psoriatic JIA is defined as the simultaneous presence of arthritis and psoriasis, which this patient has. Moreover, her family history of psoriatic arthritis puts her at increased risk for this condition. However, psoriatic JIA typically manifests with asymmetric oligoarthritis in small to medium-sized joints; coxitis is rarely the first symptom. Moreover, the acute onset of symptoms, fever, and severe joint pain are not consistent with this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Insufficient blood supply to the femoral head causes Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD). LCPD is most commonly seen in children between 4 and 10 years of age and typically manifests with a limp and unilateral hip pain referring to the leg. However, the acute onset of symptoms and the presence of fever, malaise, and local warmth and erythema are not consistent with LCPD. Moreover, in LCPD, the pain usually increases with hip abduction, whereas this patient is holding her hip abducted to relieve pain.
questions.hint: This patient is at imminent risk for joint destruction and should undergo diagnostic joint aspiration as soon as possible.

questions.text: A previously healthy 3-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents 2 days after the onset of fever and irritability. He had been well until 4 days ago when he started feeding poorly and sleeping more than usual. His mother says that he cries every time she changes his diaper. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears lethargic and irritable when roused for examination. His temperature is 38.4°C (101.4°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 92/58 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a flexed and externally rotated left leg; he starts to cry when he is picked up. Examination of the left hip shows tenderness to palpation and a limited range of motion; the left buttock is swollen. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although avascular necrosis of the femoral head manifests with groin pain, restricted range of motion, and tenderness of the hip, systemic symptoms, such as fever and lethargy, and swelling of the buttock are not expected findings. Note that avascular necrosis can be a complication of the condition seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Deep cellulitis can manifest with fever, pain, tenderness, and swelling of the affected area (e.g., buttock). However, deep cellulitis is characterized by poorly defined, indurated, and erythematous lesions. Moreover, additional findings such as lymphangitis, bullae, and/or purulent exudate are commonly seen. Deep cellulitis may precede the condition seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Developmental dysplasia of the hip is characterized by hip instability, subluxation/dislocation of the femoral head, and/or acetabular dysplasia in a developing hip joint. However, this condition is typically asymptomatic in a child aged < 6 months and is generally not associated with systemic findings such as fever and lethargy.

D) CORRECT:

Septic arthritis in neonates and young infants typically initially manifests with nonspecific features (irritability, poor feeding, fever, sleeping more than usual, lethargy), and symptoms of joint involvement can be subtle (e.g., crying when the diaper is changed, unilateral swelling of the buttock, inability to bear weight). Common findings suggestive of bacterial coxitis include tenderness of the hip and restricted range of motion, as seen here. The affected extremity is often flexed and externally rotated in order to decrease intraarticular pressure and alleviate pain.

Bacterial coxitis is an orthopedic emergency because of the risk of potentially catastrophic complications (e.g., joint destruction, septic shock, avascular necrosis) and requires prompt arthrocentesis and culture for diagnosis. Treatment consists of simultaneous parenteral antibiotic therapy (e.g., vancomycin, cefazolin) and evacuation of purulent material (e.g., drainage, lavage, or debridement).

E) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis is a common cause of acute hip pain in children and is more commonly seen in boys than girls. Moreover, a flexed externally rotated hip and a limited range of motion of the affected hip are typical findings. However, this condition is not associated with systemic symptoms such as lethargy, and patients typically appear well. Furthermore, transient synovitis most commonly affects children aged between 3 and 8 years.
questions.hint: Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the diagnostic modality of choice for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with acute swelling in her right knee, pain that hinders her ability to bear weight on her right leg, and a one-week history of intermittent low-grade fevers and malaise. She has a history of daily heroin use but is otherwise healthy. She reports no recent sexual activity.
On examination, her right knee is erythematous and hot, with an obvious joint effusion. She has limited and minimal range of motion of the knee. She has track marks over both antecubital fossae.
Joint aspiration shows a leukocyte count of 132,000 cells per mm3 with 95% neutrophils.
While the results of cultures from the joint aspiration are pending, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin is not adequate because it lacks coverage for MRSA.

Ertapenem would not be a good choice because it does not cover MRSA or Pseudomonas.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, whether used alone or in combination with vancomycin, is not appropriate because it does not cover P. aeruginosa.

C) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin is not adequate because it lacks coverage for MRSA.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's physical examination and laboratory findings are consistent with septic arthritis. Septic bacterial arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus spp. Patients who are sexually active are also at risk for gonococcal arthritis, and those who inject drugs are at increased risk for Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection. Given that methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection is a possibility in this case, vancomycin should be included in the empiric treatment regimen. An antipseudomonal agent, such as cefepime or piperacillin-tazobactam, is appropriate for patients who are considered to be at risk for pseudomonal infection.

Once culture results from the joint aspiration are available, antibiotic therapy should be narrowed to cover the responsible organism.

Key learning point: Empiric antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis in a patient who injects drugs should include coverage for common organisms and for these two possible sources of infection: methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, whether used alone or in combination with vancomycin, is not appropriate because it does not cover P. aeruginosa.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man with a history of hypertension and bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees presents with severe pain and swelling of his left knee that began 3 days ago. He has also had chills and decreased energy. He denies any recent trauma to the knee.
Physical examination reveals a hot, erythematous knee with a significant joint effusion and decreased range of motion. Aspirate of the knee joint reveals a leukocyte count of 90,000 per mm3 with 95% neutrophils. Gram stain of the joint fluid shows gram-positive cocci.
Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute septic arthritis typically manifests as pain and swelling of the affected joint, with physical examination showing inflammatory changes and joint aspirate showing an elevated leukocyte count. Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent causative agent in adults (isolated in 37% to 56% of cases). Risk factors for septic arthritis include extremes of age (being very old or very young), immunosuppressive disease, recent joint surgery, and underlying joint disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis. Management of acute septic arthritis includes targeted antimicrobial therapy and either joint fluid aspiration or arthrotomy with debridement.

Key learning point: The most common agent causing acute septic arthritis with gram-positive cocci seen on Gram stain of the joint fluid is Staphylococcus aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active adults, but the organism is a gram-negative coccus that is infrequently seen on Gram stain.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

E) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man with liver disease related to alcohol use disorder presents with acute-onset pain in his right knee and left wrist. He developed community-acquired pneumonia one week ago, after a camping trip to Connecticut. His symptoms at that time included cough productive of green sputum and pleuritic chest pain; a chest radiograph showed a focal consolidation in the right lower lobe. He did not take antibiotics and since then has been feeling progressively worse. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On examination, his temperature is 38.2°C. He has a loud holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla that is new, and he has dullness in the right base with egophony. His right knee and left wrist both appear hot, swollen, and tender, with very limited passive range of motion.
Which one of the following organisms is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Borrelia burgdorferi, the agent of Lyme disease, is a tickborne infection that frequently causes a monoarthritis with swelling out of proportion to pain, typically in the knee in late-disseminated disease. Polyarthritis can also occur. However, B. burgdorferi does not typically cause pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections typically occur in younger patients and can cause a monoarticular arthritis, an asymmetric polyarticular arthritis, or, in disseminated disease, the triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis, and polyarthralgia.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae is a less common cause of community-acquired pneumonia than S. pneumoniae in patients without chronic disease and is less likely to cause endocarditis and septic arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Most cases of septic arthritis are caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus species and affect a single joint. Involvement of more than one joint is less common but may occur in patients with high-grade bacteremia, including endocarditis, or with underlying connective tissues diseases. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most likely pathogen in a patient who has two septic joints, endocarditis, and community-acquired pneumonia. Risk factors for invasive pneumococcal infection — and pneumococcal endocarditis — include liver disease and immunosuppression. S. pneumoniae endocarditis often causes large vegetations and may have a fulminant course.

Key learning point: Septic arthritis of more than one joint in the context of pneumonia and endocarditis is most likely to be caused by infection with Streptococcus pneumoniae.

E) INCORRECT:

S. aureus infection can mimic this picture and is the most common agent in nongonococcal bacterial arthritis, but it is a very uncommon cause of community-acquired pneumonia except after influenza; this patient did not have a preceding influenza-like illness that would place him at risk for S. aureus pneumonia. Community-acquired multidrug-resistant S. aureus pneumonia typically manifests as a multifocal, necrotizing pneumonia that should be treated initially in the hospital. Risk factors for community-acquired multidrug-resistant S. aureus pneumonia include immunocompromised states, crowded living conditions, injection-drug use, male-to-male sexual contact, and recent influenza-like illness.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old man is hospitalized for evaluation of right-knee pain that has progressively worsened for 2 weeks. Six years ago, he underwent a total-knee arthroplasty of the same knee.
On examination, he is afebrile and has a mild effusion of the right knee.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests should be the next step in evaluating this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bone scan is sensitive but lacks sufficient specificity, and bone remodeling around an implant can result in a positive study for up to a year after surgery.

B) INCORRECT:

Neither MRI nor CT accurately discriminates between infection and mechanical failure.

C) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures have a sensitivity of 56% to 75% for detecting infection. In the absence of systemic symptoms, blood cultures are likely to be negative.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither MRI nor CT accurately discriminates between infection and mechanical failure.

E) CORRECT:

Clinicians should consider the possibility of prosthetic joint infection in any patient with a history of total joint replacement and new-onset swelling. A plain-film radiograph that reveals periprosthetic lucency and loosening of the tibial components of a joint prosthesis provides supportive data that infection may be present, but this is not pathognomonic. Joint aspiration is needed to distinguish between aseptic mechanical failure and infection; optimally, it should precede administration of systemic antibiotics. Typically, such a procedure would be done by an orthopedic surgeon or interventional radiologist when such an individual is readily available. The presence of leukocytes >1700/mm3 is consistent with prosthetic joint infection.

Notably, patients with delayed-onset infections (>3 months after surgery) often lack fever, leukocytosis, or local symptoms over the joint. The reason for the lack of these symptoms is that the most common organisms causing these infections are relatively low-virulence bacteria, most commonly coagulase negative staphylococci. By contrast, early-onset infections (<3 months) are most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, and fever, erythema, and pain are generally present.

Key learning point: The most useful diagnostic test for a patient with suspected prosthetic joint infection is aspiration of the affected joint.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis is hospitalized with one week of productive cough, fevers to 40°C, and hypotension. Her rheumatoid arthritis was diagnosed at age 20 and has been well controlled with methotrexate and etanercept for the past year. She received prednisone for the first 2 months after her diagnosis but not thereafter.
On physical examination, her temperature is 39.4°C, her heart rate is 112 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 79/52 mm Hg, and her oxygen saturation is 94% while she is breathing ambient air. Crackles are noted diffusely throughout her lungs. Her left knee is swollen, red, painful, and warm; with 5 degrees of flexion or extension, she develops extreme pain. She has no evidence of chronic joint deformity on examination.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Her peripheral leukocyte count is 17,000 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 95% neutrophils (40–70).
After she is given 2 liters of normal saline intravenously, her blood pressure is 108/72 mm Hg. After blood cultures and a chest radiograph are obtained, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated.
Which one of the following next steps is best in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Intra-articular glucocorticoid injection into the affected knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular glucocorticoid injection is contraindicated until a septic knee is ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral or intravenous glucocorticoids might worsen an underlying infectious state if they are given in the absence of appropriate antibiotics, and there is no reason to suspect that the patient has adrenal insufficiency, given that she has not received glucocorticoids to treat her rheumatoid arthritis. According to a single study, after confirmation that appropriate antibiotics are being used to treat a septic joint, the addition of glucocorticoids may be beneficial; however, more studies are needed before this approach can be recommended. Studies of the routine addition of glucocorticoids during sepsis treatment have had conflicting results; most recent studies have shown that glucocorticoids are associated with a shorter duration of vasopressor support in septic shock, but there is no consistent evidence of a mortality benefit.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee could confirm an effusion, but it would not establish the cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Chest CT would be useful in looking for an effusion or pneumonia only if the chest radiograph were normal, but findings suggestive of bacterial pneumonia would not change initial management.

E) CORRECT:

The use of tumor necrosis factor inhibitors in patients with rheumatoid arthritis has resulted in substantial clinical and functional improvement. However, those drugs increase the chance of developing a serious infection — in particular, a severe respiratory or skin infection. This patient is likely to have developed sepsis in the setting of pneumonia, warranting further evaluation with blood cultures and a chest radiograph. A knee arthrocentesis is also needed to evaluate the knee joint, because diagnosing an infected joint would change management and length of treatment. Antibiotics alone are not adequate therapy for septic joints. Septic joints are considered closed abscesses, so joint drainage is typically necessary with needle aspiration, arthroscopic drainage, or surgical drainage. Needle aspiration may be as effective as surgical drainage and may result in shorter hospital stays and improved functional status at 3 months. However, if adequate drainage is not achieved with needle aspiration, surgery may be required.

Key learning point: In an immunosuppressed patient who is likely to have bacteremia, a swollen, warm joint with limited range of motion should be treated as a septic joint, until proven otherwise.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis that is treated with methotrexate presents to the emergency department reporting increased pain, swelling, and erythema in his left knee during the past 3 days. Six weeks earlier, he underwent a total left-knee replacement, and his recovery had been going well, without new trauma.
His rheumatoid arthritis has involved his metacarpophalangeal joints, wrists, knees, and feet bilaterally, but only the left knee bothers him currently.
In the emergency department, the patient has a temperature of 37.9°C, a heart rate of 87 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 136/84 mm Hg. Examination of his left knee reveals a moderate effusion with warmth and tenderness; extension and flexion are limited by pain. Examination of the rest of his joints is normal.
Laboratory evaluation reveals normal creatinine and electrolyte levels, normal results on liver function tests, and a normal hematocrit. The leukocyte count is 11,200 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000), the erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 52 mm/hr (0–17), and the C-reactive protein level is 67 mg/liter (0.08–3.10).
What is the most appropriate next step for establishing a diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Examination of the knee under anesthesia
Trial of low-dose oral prednisone (10 mg daily)

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Neither an MRI nor an examination under anesthesia would be likely to provide useful information, because they cannot distinguish between infectious and noninfectious causes of inflammation.

B) CORRECT:

The differential diagnosis for acute monoarthritis includes infection, crystalline disease, sterile inflammatory arthritis, and hemarthrosis. However, the evaluation for a possible septic joint is of primary importance. Both a history of rheumatoid arthritis and a history of recent joint surgery considerably increase the likelihood of a septic joint. Arthrocentesis with Gram stain and culture of the synovial fluid is required to evaluate for infection. Of note, arthrocentesis of a prosthetic joint requires an experienced provider and aseptic conditions to ensure that infection is not introduced into an uninfected joint. Ideally, empiric antibiotics would be started only after synovial fluid is obtained for culture. Infection of a prosthetic joint requires surgery in addition to intravenous antibiotics.

Key learning point: The most appropriate evaluation for a patient who recently underwent total-knee replacement and who presents with features that suggest infection in the prosthetic joint is arthrocentesis from that joint.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither an MRI nor an examination under anesthesia would be likely to provide useful information, because they cannot distinguish between infectious and noninfectious causes of inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

A nuclear bone scan can identify loosening of a prosthetic joint, which can occur from smoldering infection or mechanical breakdown of the prosthesis (or any cementing material). However, a nuclear bone scan is inadequate in this patient with acute prosthetic-joint septic arthritis, as it does not further the process of identifying the causative microbiologic organism.

E) INCORRECT:

A trial of low-dose oral prednisone can be diagnostically helpful in a patient with rheumatoid arthritis having a flare. However, it is not appropriate in this patient, whose presentation is concerning for acute prosthetic-joint septic arthritis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis treated with methotrexate and etanercept presents with a 3-day history of pain and swelling in her right knee. She reports no precipitating trauma. The patient had been stable without rheumatoid arthritis flares since etanercept was added to her methotrexate regimen 9 months ago. She has had minimal previous involvement in her knees. She denies overt fever, worsening morning stiffness, or problems with any joints other than the knee.
On examination, she has a temperature of 37.2°C, a blood pressure of 104/80 mm Hg, and a heart rate of 102 beats per minute. Her right knee is notably swollen and warm, with moderate effusion. She cannot fully flex her right knee. No other joints show evidence of synovitis.
Laboratory testing reveals a leukocyte count of 8900/mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000) with 70% neutrophils (reference range, 40–70). The rest of the complete blood count is normal, as are liver- and renal-function studies. Rheumatoid-factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibodies are strongly positive.
Analysis of 15 mL of thick, cloudy synovial fluid aspirated from the right knee reveals a leukocyte count of 35,000 per mm3 with 90% neutrophils. Crystal examination and Gram stain are negative. Joint fluid culture is pending.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Inject methylprednisolone into the knee joint
Begin targeted antibiotics if the synovial fluid culture is positive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral or intra-articular glucocorticoid therapy should not be initiated in a patient with suspected septic arthritis while empiric antibiotic therapy is being initiated.

B) INCORRECT:

Switching the biologic therapy is not indicated unless it becomes clear that the current presentation is due to worsening rheumatoid arthritis and not infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Because septic arthritis can be rapidly destructive, parenteral antibiotics should be administered immediately after the arthrocentesis, even if Gram stain is negative. The antibiotic regimen can be modified, if necessary, after culture results are available.

D) CORRECT:

Septic arthritis is a potential concern in a patient with underlying rheumatoid arthritis (RA) on immunosuppressive therapy who presents with acute monoarticular joint pain and swelling, in the absence of other joint involvement. Compared with the general population, patients with RA are at greatly increased risk for infectious arthritis. The affected joint should be aspirated, and the fluid should be sent for culture.

Because septic arthritis can be rapidly destructive, parenteral antibiotics should be administered immediately after the arthrocentesis, even if Gram stain is negative. The antibiotic regimen can be modified, if necessary, after culture results are available. Although the majority of septic joint effusions have leukocyte counts >50,000/mm3, and the majority of noninfected effusions have counts <50,000/mm3, this cutoff point has poor sensitivity and specificity for infection. Notably, patients on immunosuppressive therapy may not have typical features of infection (high leukocyte count, high fevers), so suspicion must remain high.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in managing a patient with rheumatoid arthritis and acute monoarthritis is to aspirate synovial fluid and start parenteral antibiotics until culture results are available.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral or intra-articular glucocorticoid therapy should not be initiated in a patient with suspected septic arthritis while empiric antibiotic therapy is being initiated. Several randomized trials have suggested that systemic glucocorticoids may be beneficial in children with septic arthritis, but studies have not been conducted in adults.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with no prior medical problems reports a one-week history of pain and swelling in her left knee that has become progressively worse. She denies any trauma to the joint. She has also developed fevers, chills, and dysuria.
On examination, her temperature is 37.7°C, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Her left knee is warm, with decreased range of motion and a large effusion. A full neurologic and skin examination reveals no abnormalities.
Urinalysis reveals 2+ leukocyte esterase and no blood. Lyme antibody testing is negative. Blood and urine cultures have no growth.
A radiograph of the knee reveals an effusion without bony abnormalities. Arthrocentesis yields cloudy synovial fluid with a total leukocyte count of 52,500 cells per mm3 with 95% neutrophils. The synovial fluid contains no crystals and is sterile by evaluation with Gram stain and culture.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A serum uric acid test is not appropriate, as gout is unlikely given the absence of crystals in the synovial fluid aspirate.

B) CORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae causes arthritis in two ways. In the first, disseminated gonococcal infection, the pathogen spreads through the bloodstream, causing pustular or vesiculopustular skin lesions, constitutional symptoms, and tenosynovitis or arthritis that is often sterile. In the second, the pathogen causes true joint infection that manifests as a monoarticular or oligoarticular purulent arthritis, often without other symptoms or findings, although symptoms of disseminated infection can precede or coexist with true joint infection; the knee is the joint most commonly affected. N. gonorrhoeae is difficult to culture; blood and synovial fluid cultures are negative in approximately 50% of patients.

If synovial fluid cultures are negative, nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites should be performed. Because even this type of testing is imperfect, empiric treatment with antibiotics is often appropriate. Symptoms of gonococcal infection often improve rapidly with treatment. Chlamydia testing is done to distinguish reactive arthritis (which can be triggered by Chlamydia) from gonococcal infection.

Key learning point: The most appropriate diagnostic test for a woman with dysuria, pyuria, and an acute monoarthritis whose synovial fluid cultures are negative is nucleic acid amplification tests or culture for Neisseria gonorrhoeae of urogenital and extragenital sites.

C) INCORRECT:

An MRI of the knee is useful to evaluate the etiology of a noninflammatory joint effusion, but it is not useful in diagnosing early inflammatory arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody testing are not priorities in this setting.
