Rheumatoid arthritis and lupus are unusual causes of monoarthritis, although a patient with these disorders may have monoarthritis as the initial presentation. In addition, the acuity of the clinical presentation in this case is not classic for rheumatoid arthritis or lupus and would make these diagnoses less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody testing are not priorities in this setting. Rheumatoid arthritis and lupus are unusual causes of monoarthritis, although a patient with these disorders may have monoarthritis as the initial presentation. In addition, the acuity of the clinical presentation in this case is not classic for rheumatoid arthritis or lupus and would make these diagnoses less likely.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute pain and swelling in the right knee, as well as lightheadedness and chills. He reports that the pain started 2 days earlier. He is no longer ambulatory, has no notable medical history, and takes no medications. He denies trauma or any history of similar joint pain.
He has a temperature of 38.6°C, a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, a heart rate of 115 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. Physical examination reveals a large effusion at the right knee, with warmth and tenderness to palpation and limited range of motion. All other joints exhibit normal range of motion with no pain on palpation.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A plain-film radiograph of the right knee reveals swelling and chondrocalcinosis but no fracture.
Arthrocentesis is performed. Synovial-fluid analysis reveals a leukocyte count of 125,000 per mm3 (definitive inflammation is present at >2000/mm3) with 98% neutrophils. Microscopy shows rare intracellular, rhomboid-shaped crystals with weakly positive birefringence. Gram stain shows no organisms. Culture results are pending.
Which one of the following initial empiric treatments, if any, is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis rapidly causes permanent joint damage, so suspected infectious arthritis requires empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy while culture results are pending. The treatment should include ceftriaxone for coverage of both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and vancomycin to cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to receiving antibiotic therapy, patients with septic arthritis may need orthopedic evaluation for irrigation and debridement to treat the infected joint. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

C) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

D) CORRECT:

Acute monoarthritis can be caused by infection, inflammation, or trauma. Crystal arthritis due to gout or to acute calcium pyrophosphate crystal arthritis (pseudogout) is the most common cause of acute inflammatory monoarthritis and can lead to fever and a high leukocyte count in synovial fluid, but the higher the leukocyte count and the higher the percentage of neutrophils, the more important it is to treat empirically for septic arthritis while awaiting culture results.

A leukocyte count >100,000 per mm3 is particularly suggestive of infectious arthritis but can also be seen in noninfectious conditions; such a presentation is often termed “pseudoseptic.” Of note, the leukocyte count is frequently much lower in prosthetic-joint infections than in natural joints; the cutoff value in suspected prosthetic-joint infections may be as low as 3000 cells per mm3 . Gram staining identifies no organisms in at least 20% of septic arthritis cases and is particularly likely to be negative in septic arthritis that is due to gonococci or gram-negative organisms.

Septic arthritis rapidly causes permanent joint damage, so suspected infectious arthritis requires empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy while culture results are pending. The treatment should include ceftriaxone for coverage of both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and vancomycin to cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to receiving antibiotic therapy, patients with septic arthritis may need orthopedic evaluation for irrigation and debridement to treat the infected joint.

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

Key learning point: While culture findings from a patient with suspected septic arthritis are pending, empiric antibiotic treatment should include ceftriaxone and vancomycin.

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman reports two weeks of progressive right-knee pain that is present when she is standing or walking but that improves with rest. The knee has also been increasingly swollen during the past week.
The patient’s medical history is significant for a total replacement of the right knee 20 years ago because of psoriatic arthritis. She also has hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and chronic kidney disease with a baseline estimated glomerular filtration rate of 30 mL/min/1.73 m2 (reference range, ≥60). Her current medications are lisinopril 5 mg daily, metformin 500 mg twice daily, and a tumor necrosis factor inhibitor (golimumab 50 mg via subcutaneous injection every 4 weeks). She has no medication allergies.
She is afebrile and has a blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg and a heart rate of 60 beats per minute. Her BMI is 40. Her right knee appears swollen with a positive bulge sign. There is no overlying erythema or warmth. Flexion is restricted to 100 degrees, and extension is restricted to 10 degrees. The patient has an antalgic gait. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Laboratory findings are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
10,000
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
12.0
12.0–16.0


Platelet count (per mm3)
350,000
150,000–350,000

135
136–145

4.0
3.5–5.0

21
21–30

105
98–106

1.6
0.6–1.1

33

Bilateral knee radiographs reveal a right-knee prosthesis in the expected position, with surrounding soft-tissue swelling and evidence of effusion.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Refer for aspiration of the prosthetic knee joint
Obtain labeled leukocyte imaging combined with bone imaging
Refer for glucocorticoid injection into the prosthetic knee joint

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a prosthetic joint, an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection or oral glucocorticoid (e.g., prednisone) is not recommended for treating an inflammatory arthropathy without first ruling out a prosthetic joint infection.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with pain and swelling in a prosthetic knee joint, and the most important diagnosis to consider is septic arthritis. Septic arthritis is more common in prosthetic knees than in prosthetic hips or shoulders and is most common in the first 2 years after surgery.

An infection in a prosthetic joint may be more likely than one in a native joint to manifest atypically without fever or warmth, and this patient’s diabetes mellitus and immunosuppression from golimumab could blunt the typical inflammatory response. These factors, combined with the patient’s psoriatic arthritis and chronic kidney disease, make septic arthritis more likely, more subtle in presentation, and more dangerous than it would be in a patient with a native joint and no immunosuppression. Fever and leukocytosis are often not present in these patients, and the course can be more indolent. Radiographs often show nonspecific findings; thus, a negative radiograph is insufficient to rule out a prosthetic joint infection.

Risk Factors for Prosthetic Joint Infection:

Current guidelines from the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons list several clinical features that raise the probability of infection in a patient presenting with pain or stiffness in a prosthetic joint:

• Physical examination findings such as warmth, effusion, redness, swelling, or a sinus tract associated with the joint
• Early implant loosening or osteolysis (as detected by radiograph)
• Presence of any of the following risk factors for joint infections: prior joint infection; superficial surgical-site infection; bacteremia within the past year; active infection at another site, including at another prosthetic joint; skin disorders such as psoriasis, lymphedema, or skin ulcers; intravenous drug use; immunosuppression, including from HIV infection, general medical problems (such as diabetes mellitus, hepatitis, renal disease, liver failure, malnourishment, sickle cell disease, and hemophilia), medications (chemotherapy, monoclonal antibodies, glucocorticoids), autoimmune diseases, inflammatory arthritis, or solid-organ transplant

It should be noted that dental work is not a risk factor for prosthetic joint infections, and, antibiotic prophylaxis during dental procedures is therefore not indicated in patients with prosthetic joints.

Evaluating for Possible Prosthetic Joint Infection:

Current guidelines recommend measuring the C-reactive protein (CRP) level and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) as a first step in evaluating for possible prosthetic joint infection. If the ESR or CRP level is significantly elevated (as in this case), joint aspiration is recommended to assess for prosthetic joint infection. Aspiration of a prosthetic joint should only be performed by experienced providers using sterile technique.

Key learning point: A patient with a knee prosthesis who is taking immunosuppressive medication and presents with knee pain and effusion, as well as elevated inflammatory markers, should undergo aspiration of the prosthetic knee joint to assess for joint infection.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug therapy (e.g., with naproxen) should be avoided in patients with chronic kidney disease and would not help establish the diagnosis in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Nuclear imaging can be considered in patients in whom a diagnosis of periprosthetic joint infection has not been established, typically in patients with a high probability of infection but nondiagnostic results of joint aspiration. It is not the correct next step in this patient, as joint aspiration should be performed first and would be more likely to yield a definitive diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

In a patient with a prosthetic joint, an intra-articular glucocorticoid injection or oral glucocorticoid (e.g., prednisone) is not recommended for treating an inflammatory arthropathy without first ruling out a prosthetic joint infection.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department reporting 24 hours of worsening redness and swelling in his right knee. He underwent right total-knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis 3 months ago but has an otherwise unremarkable medical history. He complains of fevers, right-knee stiffness, and severe pain with any movement of the knee or any attempt to bear weight on it.
He is currently afebrile and has a blood pressure of 152/90 mm Hg and a heart rate of 96 beats per minute. His right knee is erythematous and warm to the touch. He is guarding his knee and resists all active and passive range of motion because of pain.
A complete blood count shows an elevated leukocyte count with a neutrophilic differential. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.
Synovial fluid analysis reveals cloudy yellow fluid with low viscosity, 30,000 leukocytes per mm3 (reference range, <200), and no crystals. Gram stain does not reveal any visible bacteria.
What is the best initial medical treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin would be a reasonable antibiotic choice if culture data reveal methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus infection, but it would not be an appropriate choice for empiric therapy as it would not treat methicillin-resistant strains. Gentamicin is not usually given for empiric treatment of a prosthetic joint infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Colchicine is used to treat acute gout flares, but this patient’s joint aspirate has no evidence of crystals, and he shows no other indication of a gout attack.

C) INCORRECT:

Injection of glucocorticoids into a prosthetic joint is not appropriate when a joint infection is suspected.

D) CORRECT:

Septic arthritis should be suspected in a patient with acute onset of joint pain, inability to bear weight, and synovial fluid analysis showing an elevated leukocyte count of 50,000 to 100,000 cells per mm3 and at least 75% neutrophils. However, the intra-articular cutoff value for infection in patients with prosthetic joint infections may be as low as 3000 cells per mm3 . Gram stain may be helpful but is negative in up to 40% of cases. Plain radiographs can reveal new subperiosteal bone growth and transcortical sinus tracts, both of which are specific for infection.

In a patient with a prosthetic joint, early detection of septic arthritis, followed by appropriate treatment with surgical debridement and intravenous antibiotics, is key to preventing long-term joint morbidity.

Intravenous vancomycin is the antibiotic most likely to be effective in a patient with a prosthetic joint whose joint aspirate reveals features of septic arthritis, because the majority of these infections are caused by gram-positive cocci (Staphylococcus and Streptococcus species). Until culture results and bacterial sensitivities are available, it is reasonable to also empirically cover gram-negative bacteria with ceftriaxone (in addition to the vancomycin).

Key learning point: The most appropriate initial medical treatment for septic arthritis in a prosthetic joint is vancomycin plus ceftriaxone.

E) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin is not an appropriate initial choice for managing septic arthritis in a prosthetic joint, as it is not effective against gram-positive cocci. However, the drug can be used in the presence of gram-negative infections, especially in patients with penicillin allergy.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever and right-sided limp. His mother reports that he had a cough and rhinitis for several days before the fever but has otherwise been well; there is no history of trauma. Testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
He refuses to bear weight on his right leg and is irritable when his right lower limb is palpated.
His temperature is 40.5°C, and his heart rate is 130 beats per minute. His right knee is swollen, red, and warm with an effusion. There is limited range of motion in flexion and extension of the knee.
These findings are most consistent with which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever can cause fever and arthritis, especially after a recent pharyngeal infection with Streptococcus pyogenes. However, it is rare in the United States in children younger than 4 years of age, and the latency period between streptococcal infection and rheumatic fever is typically 2 to 3 weeks. The diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever can be established by performing a test for recent streptococcal infection as well as evaluation for the presence of Jones criteria.

B) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is a noninfectious syndrome that involves avascular necrosis of the hip and affects children 4 to 10 years of age. It manifests with hip pain and limp.

C) CORRECT:

Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis. Bacterial infection of the hip is a surgical emergency, because a delay in drainage can lead to aseptic necrosis of the hip and long-term complications.

Septic arthritis in children usually results from hematogenous spread from a focus of infection elsewhere in the body; upper respiratory infections precede septic arthritis in up to 50% of cases. Joint pain is usually severe, and the infected joint and periarticular tissues are swollen, hot, and sometimes erythematous. Passive and active motion of the joint is severely, often completely, restricted. Knees, hips, ankles, and elbows account for 90% of infected joints in children.

Even with early and appropriate antibiotic treatment, permanent joint damage is common, and therefore septic arthritis should always be ruled out and even treated empirically when clinical suspicion is high. Staphylococcus aureus and nongroup A and B streptococci are the most common causes of septic arthritis in children overall, but other organisms are particularly prevalent in certain age groups, such as Kingella kingae in young children and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in neonates and adolescents. Consideration of concomitant osteomyelitis is important in cases of septic arthritis, particularly in young children, as the presence of bone infection has implications for antibiotic duration.

Key learning point: Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is a multisystemic febrile illness; arthritis is an unusual manifestation and is not one of the diagnostic criteria. Furthermore, other than fever, this child has none of the other criteria needed to make a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis often follows a recent upper respiratory infection but does not usually cause a fever. It is among the most common causes of hip pain in young children; some children may report medial thigh or knee pain.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy presents with 2 days of fever, a limp, and a red and swollen left knee. He has no history of recent trauma or illness.
His temperature is 39.2°C. His left knee is warm, erythematous, and tender with limited range of motion and an effusion.
After blood testing, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Arrange for MRI of the left knee
Initiate treatment with oxacillin and gentamicin
Initiate treatment with cephalexin and vancomycin

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pyogenic (septic) arthritis accounts for approximately 6.5% of all childhood arthritides and is most common in children younger than 2 years of age. Joint pain is usually severe, and the infected joint and periarticular tissues are swollen, hot, and sometimes erythematous. Passive and active motion of the joint is severely, often completely, restricted. Knees, hips, ankles, and elbows account for 90% of infected joints in children. There is often an associated infection of the adjacent bone, particularly in young children.

Every child with acute unexplained monoarthritis should undergo aspiration of the affected joint immediately, because septic arthritis is associated with substantial morbidity. Septic arthritis is strongly suggested by cloudy or serosanguinous fluid with an elevated neutrophil count (50,000 to 300,000 per mm3), a low glucose level (<30 mg/dL), a high lactate dehydrogenase level (>500 IU), or a positive Gram stain. The culture from the joint fluid is positive in 50% to 70% of cases. Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes are the most commonly isolated organisms outside the neonatal period, and Neisseria gonorrhoeae should be considered in sexually active adolescents.

Imaging may be warranted, especially to make a diagnosis of osteomyelitis, but it is not the first diagnostic test if the examination suggests an acutely infected joint.

Key learning point: The most important diagnostic test for a young child with acute-onset fever and monoarthritis of the knee is aspiration of joint fluid.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging may be warranted, especially to make a diagnosis of osteomyelitis, but it is not the first diagnostic test if the examination suggests an acutely infected joint.

C) INCORRECT:

Treatment with empiric antibiotics should be started only after the diagnostic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Treatment with empiric antibiotics should be started only after the diagnostic evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Treatment with naproxen is inappropriate without an established diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with acute swelling in the right knee, pain that hinders her ability to bear weight on the right leg, and a one-week history of intermittent low-grade fevers and malaise. She has a history of daily injection-drug use but is otherwise healthy. She reports no sexual activity.
On examination, her right knee is erythematous and hot, with an obvious joint effusion. She has limited and minimal range of motion of the knee. She has track marks over both antecubital fossae.
Joint aspiration shows a leukocyte count of 132,000 cells per mm3 with 95% neutrophils.
While awaiting the results of cultures from the joint aspiration, which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin does not provide adequate coverage for MRSA. Ertapenem would not be a good choice because it lacks coverage for both MRSA and Pseudomonas.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, whether used alone or in combination with vancomycin, is not appropriate because it will not cover P. aeruginosa.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's physical examination and laboratory findings are consistent with septic arthritis. Septic bacterial arthritis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species. Patients who are sexually active are also at risk for gonococcal arthritis, and those who inject drugs are at increased risk for Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection.

Given that methicillin-resistant S. aureus (MRSA) infection is a possibility in this case, vancomycin should be included in the empiric treatment regimen. An antipseudomonal agent, such as cefepime or piperacillin-tazobactam, is appropriate for patients who are considered to be at risk for pseudomonal infection.

Once culture results from the joint aspiration are available, antibiotic therapy should be narrowed to cover the responsible organism.

Key learning point: Empiric antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis in a patient who injects drugs should include coverage for common organisms and for these two possible sources of infection: methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is not appropriate because it will not cover P. aeruginosa.

E) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin does not provide adequate coverage for MRSA.

questions.text: Which one of the following synovial-fluid findings is most suggestive of septic arthritis?

choices.text: Leukocyte count >25,000 cells/mm3 with predominant neutrophils
Leukocyte count >100,000 cells/mm3 with predominant neutrophils
Leukocyte count >40,000 cells/mm3 and positively birefringent crystals

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

There is no single cutoff for the synovial-fluid leukocyte count in the diagnosis of septic arthritis; however, the higher the count, the higher the likelihood of this condition in the right clinical context: Leukocyte counts >100,000 cells/mm3 have a likelihood ratio of 28 for septic arthritis, whereas those <25,000 cells/mm3 have a likelihood ratio of only 0.32.

B) INCORRECT:

Normal synovial fluid has a leukocyte count <200 cells/mm3 with <25% neutrophils. In noninflammatory arthritis, the leukocyte count can rise to up to 2000 cells/mm3 with <25% neutrophils.

C) CORRECT:

There is no single cutoff for the synovial-fluid leukocyte count in the diagnosis of septic arthritis; however, the higher the count, the higher the likelihood of this condition in the right clinical context: Leukocyte counts >100,000 cells/mm3 have a likelihood ratio of 28 for septic arthritis, whereas those <25,000 cells/mm3 have a likelihood ratio of only 0.32.

Key learning point: A leukocyte count >100,000 cells/mm3 on synovial fluid analysis is very suggestive of septic arthritis

D) INCORRECT:

Normal synovial fluid has a leukocyte count <200 cells/mm3 with <25% neutrophils. In noninflammatory arthritis, the leukocyte count can rise to up to 2000 cells/mm3 with <25% neutrophils.

E) INCORRECT:

Positively birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid suggest acute calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystal arthritis (previously known as pseudogout); although a patient may present with both septic arthritis and acute CPP crystal arthritis, this would be very rare.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of excruciating left knee pain for 4 days. He underwent a total knee arthroplasty of his left knee joint 4 months ago. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis. Current medications include glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen left knee joint; range of motion is limited by pain. Analysis of the synovial fluid confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis has the ability to form a biofilm. It can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. The patient underwent an arthroplasty in his left knee 4 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 months after surgery.

If the patient's infection had developed either < 3 months or > 12 months after surgery, Staphylococcus aureus would be the most likely causal organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a possible cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. However, this patient has no history of immunodeficiency, making this answer unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, patients with joint infection due to S. aureus are usually acutely ill with high fever, chills, and onset of symptoms within 3 months after arthroplasty (when the infection is acquired during implantation) or after 12 months from surgery (due to hematogenous infection). Given the fact that this patient presents 4 months after surgery, an infection with a less virulent pathogen is more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. This patient has no history of conditions that would increase the risk of P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., malignancy, HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), which makes this answer unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae, a group B Streptococcus, does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this answer unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with a tender and swollen knee and low-grade fever is consistent with septic arthritis. His history of arthroplasty makes a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely, even 4 months after the operation.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of severe pain in her left knee. She recently started jogging a few times per week. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with metformin and chlorothiazide. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). The left knee is swollen and tender to palpation with a significantly impaired range of motion. A 1.5-cm, painless ulcer is seen on the plantar surface of the left foot. Which of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of occult meniscal tears, which can arise from knee injuries or degenerative processes. Although there is no history of recent knee trauma, this patient recently started exercising and she could have suffered a previously undiagnosed meniscal tear. However, meniscal tears cannot explain this patient's fever, and in the presence of a distant wound site, another diagnosis would be more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is the best next step in this patient with typical symptoms of septic arthritis, including fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion. The knee is a commonly affected joint in septic arthritis, which is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site, such as an infected diabetic ulcer. Typical findings in arthrocentesis include a synovial fluid WBC count of over 50,000/μL with dominance of polymorphonuclear cells (PMN).

Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric treatment for septic arthritis (parenteral antibiotics based on the Gram stain) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage, which is primarily caused by bacterial invasion of cartilage.

Key learning point: Arthrocentesis is the most important diagnostic test for suspected septic arthritis, as it allows for synovial fluid analysis and culture to confirm infection and guide treatment.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

C) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 can aid in the diagnosis of reactive arthritis, which usually presents with fever and lower extremity joint pain. However, it typically presents as asymmetrical polyarthritis that is often combined with sacroiliitis and extra‑articular symptoms (e.g., conjunctivitis or anterior uveitis), which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this patient lacks symptoms of a preceding infection such as diarrhea or dysuria.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor test can aid in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can affect the knee joints. However, it would typically present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the finger and wrist joints, morning stiffness, and constitutional symptoms, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum uric acid levels can be elevated in patients with gout. This patient's use of thiazide diuretics and diabetes mellitus put her at increased risk for gout. She also has some typical findings of an acute gout attack such as joint pain, swelling, and restricted range of motion. However, the presence of a distant wound site makes another diagnosis more likely. Furthermore, serum uric acid levels can be normal, raised, or even low during an acute gouty attack. Therefore, measuring serum uric acid levels may not be useful in diagnosis.
questions.hint: Permanent joint destruction is a dreaded complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of a 3-day history of worsening pain in her right hip and thigh. During this time, she has also had fever, fatigue, and malaise. Her father says she has been limping for the past 2 days. She does not remember any trauma. She is on a soccer team but missed the last training due to a cold. She has a history of psoriasis treated with topical steroids. Her temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 95/57 mm Hg. She holds her right leg in a flexed, abducted, and externally rotated position during the examination. The area over the right hip joint is warm to the touch and reddened. The right hip and thigh are tender to palpation and attempts to passively or actively move the upper leg cause severe discomfort. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Direct inoculation of a pathogen into the hip joint cavity
Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck
Hematogenous spread of infection to the hip joint
Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the hip joint synovium
Insufficient blood supply to the femoral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis of the hip can be caused by direct inoculation of bacteria secondary to iatrogenic interventions (e.g., arthrocentesis, arthroscopy) or trauma (e.g., open wounds around the joint, penetrating trauma). However, this patient has no history of recent joint procedure or trauma, and physical examination did not show open wounds around the hip joint, so a different etiology is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Displacement of the femoral epiphysis from the femoral neck (i.e., slipped capital femoral epiphysis, SCFE) can cause acute onset severe hip pain, limping, and restricted movement of the affected hip, which this patient has. Moreover, SCFE is more common in obese children, like this patient. However, affected children are typically > 10 years of age. Moreover, this patient is holding her hip abducted for pain relief, whereas in SCFE abduction is reduced and painful. Finally, fever and local warmth and erythema are not expected in patients with SCFE.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with characteristic symptoms of septic arthritis of the hip (bacterial coxitis), including fever, joint pain, restricted range of motion, local erythema and warmth, and typical hip position (i.e., flexed, abducted, externally rotated). This condition is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site or due to a recent upper respiratory tract or gastrointestinal infection. Bacterial coxitis is a rare condition and an orthopedic emergency that requires prompt arthrocentesis and culture for diagnosis. Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric broad spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy for septic arthritis (e.g., vancomycin, cefazolin) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage. Additionally, drainage with debridement of necrotic tissue and lavage should be performed to decompress the joint; the hip joint is usually approached via open surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune-mediated inflammation of the hip joint synovium can be seen in patients with juvenile psoriatic arthritis (psoriatic JIA). Psoriatic JIA is defined as the simultaneous presence of arthritis and psoriasis. However, psoriatic JIA typically manifests with asymmetric oligoarthritis in small to medium-sized joints; coxitis is rarely the first symptom. Moreover, the acute onset of symptoms, fever, and severe joint pain are not consistent with this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Insufficient blood supply to the femoral head causes Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD). LCPD is most commonly seen in children between 4 and 10 years of age and typically manifests with a limp and unilateral hip pain referring to the leg. However, the acute onset of symptoms and the presence of fever, malaise, and local warmth and erythema are not consistent with LCPD. Moreover, in LCPD, the pain usually increases with hip abduction, whereas this patient is holding her hip abducted to relieve pain.
questions.hint: This patient is at imminent risk for joint destruction and should undergo diagnostic joint aspiration as soon as possible.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of hypertension and bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees presents with severe pain and swelling of his left knee that began 3 days ago. He has also had chills and decreased energy. He denies any recent trauma to the knee. Physical examination reveals a hot, erythematous knee with a significant joint effusion and decreased range of motion. Aspirate of the knee joint reveals a leukocyte count of 90,000/mm3 with 95% neutrophils. Gram stain of the joint fluid shows gram-positive cocci. Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute septic arthritis typically manifests as pain and swelling of the affected joint, with physical examination showing inflammatory changes and joint aspirate showing an elevated leukocyte count. Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent causative agent in adults (isolated in 37% to 56% of cases). Risk factors for septic arthritis include extremes of age (being very old or very young), immunosuppressive disease, recent joint surgery, and underlying joint disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis. Management of acute septic arthritis includes targeted antimicrobial therapy and either joint fluid aspiration or arthrotomy with debridement.

Key learning point: The most common agent causing acute septic arthritis with gram-positive cocci seen on Gram stain of the joint fluid is Staphylococcus aureus.

B) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active adults, but the organism is a gram-negative coccus that is infrequently seen on Gram stain.

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

D) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

E) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)
questions.hint: This patient's joint pain, restricted range of motion of the affected joint, history of bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees, in combination with synovial fluid findings, raise suspicion for septic arthritis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of acute pain and swelling in the right knee, lightheadedness, and chills. He denies trauma or any history of similar joint pain. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F). Physical examination reveals a large effusion at the right knee, with warmth and tenderness to palpation and limited range of motion. A plain-film radiograph of the right knee reveals swelling and chondrocalcinosis but no fracture. Arthrocentesis is performed. Synovial-fluid analysis reveals a leukocyte count of 125,000/mm3 (definitive inflammation is present at >2000/mm3) with 98% neutrophils. Microscopy shows rare intracellular, rhomboid-shaped crystals with weakly positive birefringence. Gram stain shows no organisms. Culture results are pending. Which one of the following initial empiric treatments, if any, is best for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis rapidly causes permanent joint damage, so suspected infectious arthritis requires empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy while culture results are pending. The treatment should include ceftriaxone for coverage of both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and vancomycin to cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to receiving antibiotic therapy, patients with septic arthritis may need orthopedic evaluation for irrigation and debridement to treat the infected joint. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

C) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, indomethacin, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

D) CORRECT:

Septic arthritis rapidly causes permanent joint damage, so suspected infectious arthritis requires empiric intravenous antibiotic therapy while culture results are pending. The treatment should include ceftriaxone for coverage of both gram-positive and gram-negative organisms such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and vancomycin to cover methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. In addition to receiving antibiotic therapy, patients with septic arthritis may need orthopedic evaluation for irrigation and debridement to treat the infected joint.

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, colchicine, indomethacin, or intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.

The leukocyte count is frequently much lower in prosthetic-joint infections than in natural joints; the cutoff value in suspected prosthetic-joint infections may be as low as 3000 cells per mm3. Gram staining identifies no organisms in at least 20% of septic arthritis cases and is particularly likely to be negative in septic arthritis that is due to gonococci or gram-negative organisms.

Key learning point: While culture findings from a patient with suspected septic arthritis are pending, empiric antibiotic treatment should include ceftriaxone and vancomycin.

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause release of calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystals from cartilage, so the finding of such crystals intracellularly (the typical finding in an attack of acute CPP crystal arthritis) does not mean that infection has been ruled out. Analogous release of monosodium urate crystals has been reported in patients with septic arthritis and gout. Thus, intra-articular glucocorticoids, in the absence of antibiotics, would be inappropriate for a patient with suspected septic arthritis, as would observation alone.
questions.hint: Acute monoarthritis can be caused by infection, inflammation, or trauma. A leukocyte count >100,000 per mm3 is particularly suggestive of infectious arthritis.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a 3-day history of fever and right-sided limp. His mother reports that he had a cough and rhinitis for several days before the fever but has otherwise been well; there is no history of trauma. He refuses to bear weight on his right leg and is irritable when his right lower limb is palpated. His temperature is 40.5°C (105°F), and pulse is 130/min. His right knee is swollen, red, and warm with an effusion. There is limited range of motion in flexion and extension of the knee. These findings are most consistent with which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever can cause fever and arthritis, especially after a recent pharyngeal infection with Streptococcus pyogenes. However, it is rare in the United States in children younger than 4 years of age, and the latency period between streptococcal infection and rheumatic fever is typically 2 to 3 weeks. The diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever can be established by performing a test for recent streptococcal infection as well as evaluation for the presence of Jones criteria.

B) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is a noninfectious syndrome that involves avascular necrosis of the hip and affects children 4 to 10 years of age. It manifests with hip pain and limp.

C) CORRECT:

Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis. Bacterial infection of the hip is a surgical emergency, because a delay in drainage can lead to aseptic necrosis of the hip and long-term complications.

Septic arthritis in children usually results from hematogenous spread from a focus of infection elsewhere in the body; upper respiratory infections precede septic arthritis in up to 50% of cases. Joint pain is usually severe, and the infected joint and periarticular tissues are swollen, hot, and sometimes erythematous. Passive and active motion of the joint is severely, often completely, restricted. Knees, hips, ankles, and elbows account for 90% of infected joints in children.

Even with early and appropriate antibiotic treatment, permanent joint damage is common, and therefore septic arthritis should always be ruled out and even treated empirically when clinical suspicion is high. Staphylococcus aureus and nongroup A and B streptococci are the most common causes of septic arthritis in children overall, but other organisms are particularly prevalent in certain age groups, such as Kingella kingae in young children and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in neonates and adolescents. Consideration of concomitant osteomyelitis is important in cases of septic arthritis, particularly in young children, as the presence of bone infection has implications for antibiotic duration.

Key learning point: Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is a multisystemic febrile illness; arthritis is an unusual manifestation and is not one of the diagnostic criteria. Furthermore, other than fever, this child has none of the other criteria needed to make a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis often follows a recent upper respiratory infection but does not usually cause a fever. It is among the most common causes of hip pain in young children; some children may report medial thigh or knee pain.
questions.hint: Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the diagnostic modality of choice for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with two days of severe pain and swelling in his left knee. He reports difficulty bearing weight and intermittent fevers. Examination shows the knee is erythematous, warm, and markedly tender with limited range of motion (see lab results and reports).

Temperature
38.6 °C



Test
Result
Normal Values



ESR
80 mm/h
2 - 10 mm/h


C-reactive peptide
70 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Joint fluid




 WBC
68,000/µL
< 200/µL


 PMNs
90%
< 25%




Gram stain of synovial fluid: Negative
Synovial fluid culture: Negative

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease with symmetric polyarticular involvement, primarily affecting small joints. It typically evolves over weeks to months, not acutely. The high white blood cell count and neutrophilic predominance in the joint fluid, along with acute systemic symptoms, are more indicative of an infectious process than rheumatoid arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Gout typically affects the first metatarsophalangeal joint and presents with monosodium urate crystals in synovial fluid. The extremely high white blood cell count and neutrophilic predominance in the joint fluid are more consistent with infection. Additionally, the absence of urate crystals and the presence of systemic symptoms such as fever make gout less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudogout often affects older adults and is associated with calcium pyrophosphate crystals in synovial fluid. The patient's age and the absence of these crystals, along with the high inflammatory markers and systemic symptoms, suggest a more virulent process. The neutrophilic predominance in the joint fluid is more typical of infection than crystal-induced arthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Septic arthritis manifests with acute onset of a single, painful, swollen joint, often accompanied by systemic signs of infection such as fever. The elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein levels indicate significant inflammation. The synovial fluid analysis shows a high white blood cell count and neutrophilic predominance, which are indicative of an infectious process. Negative Gram stain and culture do not exclude septic arthritis, as prior antibiotic use or sampling issues can lead to false negatives. The clinical and laboratory findings strongly suggest septic arthritis.

Key learning point: Septic arthritis is characterized by acute joint pain, swelling, fever, and a very high synovial fluid WBC count, often greater than 50,000, and can occur even with negative synovial fluid cultures.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of intense pain in his right knee to the Outpatient Clinic. He reports fever, chills, and progressive difficulty bearing weight. He has a history of type 2 diabetes. Examination shows marked swelling, warmth, and limited range of motion at the right knee (see lab results).


Heart rate
108/min


Blood pressure
115/72 mm Hg


Temperature
38.5°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
14 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


C-reactive peptide
98 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L


Joint fluid




 WBC
60,000/µL
< 200/µL


 Gram stain
Negative
Negative



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the knee to evaluate for osteomyelitis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids reduce inflammation in autoimmune conditions but are inappropriate here due to the high likelihood of infection. The patient's systemic signs and elevated joint fluid WBC indicate an infectious etiology. Glucocorticoids could suppress the immune response, worsening the infection, especially in a patient with diabetes.

B) CORRECT:

The presentation of acute knee pain, swelling, fever, and elevated inflammatory markers suggests septic arthritis, especially in a patient with diabetes mellitus. Septic arthritis requires immediate empirical treatment to prevent joint damage and systemic spread, even with a negative Gram stain, as its sensitivity is low. Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics target common pathogens like Staphylococcus aureus. Early antibiotic therapy, often with joint drainage, is crucial for optimal outcomes.

Key learning point: In cases of suspected septic arthritis, characterized by acute monoarthritis with systemic signs of infection, the immediate management should include intravenous antibiotics to address the potential bacterial infection.

C) INCORRECT:

The acute presentation with severe knee pain, swelling, and systemic signs of infection, along with high joint fluid WBC, suggests septic arthritis rather than osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis typically presents insidiously and is less likely to cause such acute synovial fluid changes. MRI is useful for bony involvement but is not the immediate priority in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

The clinical and laboratory findings strongly suggest septic arthritis, necessitating prompt treatment. Delaying therapy to await culture results risks joint destruction and systemic infection spread. Empiric antibiotic therapy should begin immediately, with culture results used to tailor treatment later.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with a one-day history of severe left knee pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with oral medications. He has no history of trauma and denies joint pain in other sites. Examination shows an erythematous, warm, and tender knee with limited range of motion due to pain.

Temperature
38.9°C

Laboratory results reveal an elevated white blood cell count. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor testing is used in the assessment of rheumatoid arthritis, characterized by chronic, symmetric polyarthritis. The patient's acute monoarthritis, systemic fever, and elevated white blood cell count suggest an infectious etiology, where rheumatoid factor testing does not provide diagnostic clarity. Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with insidious onset and multi-joint involvement, features absent here.

B) CORRECT:

Synovial fluid aspiration is the definitive diagnostic procedure for suspected septic arthritis. It allows for the assessment of cell count, differential, and viscosity, typically revealing elevated white blood cell counts with neutrophil predominance in bacterial infections. Gram stain and culture identify the specific pathogen, crucial for targeted antimicrobial therapy. This procedure also helps exclude other causes of acute monoarthritis, such as crystal-induced arthropathies, by ruling out urate or calcium pyrophosphate crystals. In patients with risk factors like diabetes, prompt diagnosis and management based on synovial fluid findings are essential to prevent joint destruction and systemic complications.

Key learning point: In suspected cases of septic arthritis, the examination of joint fluid through arthrocentesis is the most important diagnostic test to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI provides detailed soft tissue imaging and can identify joint effusions and synovial thickening. However, these findings are nonspecific and do not directly identify the causative organism or assess synovial fluid characteristics. MRI requires more time for acquisition and interpretation, making it less suitable for immediate diagnostic confirmation in acute infectious arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

While broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are critical in managing septic arthritis, initiating them before obtaining diagnostic samples can lead to negative culture results. Arthrocentesis is essential for confirming septic arthritis through synovial fluid analysis, including Gram stain, culture, cell count, and crystal testing. Administering antibiotics without prior fluid analysis can obscure the causative organism, hindering definitive diagnosis and potentially leading to inappropriate therapy.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old boy presents with sudden onset of right knee pain, fever to 39.5°C, and difficulty bearing weight for the last 24 hours. His vaccinations are up to date. Examination shows a tense, swollen knee that is extremely painful with passive range of motion (see lab results and report).

Temperature
39.5°C



Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
18 x 10⁹/L
6.1-17.5 x 10⁹/L


ESR
70 mm/h
3 - 15 mm/h


C-reactive peptide
150 mg/L
< 8.2 mg/L



Synovial fluid analysis: Purulent
Which organism is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the leading cause of septic arthritis in children beyond the neonatal period. It spreads hematogenously, causing acute inflammation, as indicated by elevated white blood cell count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels. The purulent synovial fluid confirms the infectious nature. In vaccinated children, pathogens like Haemophilus influenzae type b are less likely, reinforcing the predominance of S. aureus. Its virulence factors, such as protein A and exotoxins, contribute to tissue damage, necessitating prompt treatment to prevent joint destruction.

Key learning point: In children with acute onset of joint pain, fever, and effusion, septic arthritis is likely, with Staphylococcus aureus being the most common causative organism.

B) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus pyogenes, known for causing pharyngitis and skin infections, rarely causes isolated septic arthritis in healthy children. It typically follows or coincides with soft tissue infections or bacteremia, which are not indicated here. The patient's up-to-date vaccinations further reduce the likelihood of invasive group A streptococcal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b was a common cause of septic arthritis before widespread vaccination. The patient's up-to-date immunizations significantly reduce the likelihood of Hib infection. Current vaccination protocols have dramatically decreased invasive Hib diseases, making it an unlikely cause in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria meningitidis primarily causes meningitis and meningococcemia, often with a rash and systemic signs. While it can cause septic arthritis, it usually presents with additional meningococcal features, absent in this patient. The isolated purulent knee and elevated inflammatory markers suggest a pathogen that directly seeds joints.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man presents with a three-day history of progressive right knee pain, swelling, and difficulty bearing weight to the clinic. He has poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and reports intermittent fevers and chills. Examination reveals a warm, erythematous knee joint with limited range of motion (see lab results and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
16.5 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Joint fluid




 WBC
85,000/μL
< 200/μL


 PMNs
90%
< 25%




Gram stain of synovial fluid: Gram-positive cocci in clusters
Culture of synovial fluid: Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus

Which of the following intravenous antibiotic regimens is most appropriate to initiate in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin inhibits bacterial protein synthesis and is active against some MRSA strains, but it is bacteriostatic and less suitable for severe infections like septic arthritis. The high burden of infection and culture-proven MRSA require a bactericidal agent with reliable joint penetration, which clindamycin does not provide.

B) INCORRECT:

Nafcillin is effective against methicillin-susceptible Staphylococcus aureus but not MRSA, which has the mecA gene encoding an altered penicillin-binding protein. The synovial fluid culture confirms MRSA, indicating resistance to nafcillin, making it unsuitable for this infection.

C) CORRECT:

Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a common cause of septic arthritis, especially in patients with risk factors like poorly controlled diabetes. The presence of Gram-positive cocci in clusters on Gram stain and a positive culture for MRSA necessitate an antibiotic effective against MRSA. Vancomycin, a glycopeptide antibiotic, inhibits cell wall synthesis in gram-positive organisms, including MRSA, by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of cell wall precursors. It is recommended for invasive MRSA infections due to its bactericidal activity, which is crucial to prevent joint destruction and systemic spread. Therapeutic drug monitoring is important to optimize dosing and minimize toxicity.

Key learning point: In cases of septic arthritis caused by MRSA, vancomycin is the appropriate antibiotic choice due to its effectiveness against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

D) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is effective against many community-acquired pathogens but lacks activity against MRSA due to altered penicillin-binding proteins in MRSA. The Gram stain and culture findings indicate MRSA, requiring an agent with effective MRSA coverage, making ceftriaxone inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old man presents with a 1-day history of severe left knee pain, swelling, and redness. He has difficulty bearing weight and notes a low-grade fever. He has rheumatoid arthritis and is on long-term methotrexate therapy. He denies recent trauma. Examination reveals moderate effusion, marked tenderness, and warmth over the knee (see lab result).


Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
12.5 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intra-articular glucocorticoids are used for inflammatory flares but are inappropriate in suspected septic arthritis. Injecting steroids into a potentially infected joint can worsen infection and obscure diagnosis. Infection must be ruled out with synovial fluid analysis before considering glucocorticoids.

B) INCORRECT:

MRI provides detailed soft tissue evaluation but is not the priority in suspected septic arthritis. The immediate need is joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis to identify infection. MRI is reserved for further evaluation if complications or additional information is needed after initial diagnostics.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with rheumatoid arthritis on immunosuppressive therapy, presenting with acute knee pain, swelling, and fever, arthrocentesis is crucial. It distinguishes between a rheumatoid arthritis flare and septic arthritis by providing synovial fluid for analysis, including cell count, Gram stain, culture, and crystal examination. This diagnostic step is essential to identify or exclude infection, preventing joint destruction from untreated septic arthritis. Additionally, removing excess fluid can relieve pain and pressure.

Key learning point: In cases of acute monoarthritis, especially in patients on immunosuppressive therapy, arthrocentesis is the most appropriate initial step to rule out septic arthritis by analyzing synovial fluid.

D) INCORRECT:

Empirical intravenous antibiotics are important in confirmed septic arthritis but should not precede arthrocentesis. Administering antibiotics before obtaining synovial fluid can reduce culture sensitivity, leading to false-negative results. Joint fluid analysis is necessary to confirm infection and guide appropriate treatment.

questions.text: Which one of the following synovial fluid findings is most suggestive of septic arthritis?

choices.text: Leukocyte count >100,000 cells/mm3 with predominant neutrophils.
Leukocyte count >40,000 cells/mm3 and positively birefringent crystals.
Leukocyte count >25,000 cells/mm3 with predominant neutrophils.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

There is no single cutoff for the synovial-fluid leukocyte count in the diagnosis of septic arthritis; however, the higher the count, the higher the likelihood of this condition in the right clinical context: Leukocyte counts > 100 × 109/L have a likelihood ratio of 28 for septic arthritis, whereas those < 25 × 109/L have a likelihood ratio of only 0.32.

Key learning point: A leukocyte count > 100 × 109/L on synovial fluid analysis is very suggestive of septic arthritis

B) INCORRECT:

Normal synovial fluid has a leukocyte count < 0.2 × 109/L with <25% neutrophils. In noninflammatory arthritis, the leukocyte count can rise to up to 2 × 109/L with <25% neutrophils.

C) INCORRECT:

Normal synovial fluid has a leukocyte count < 0.2 × 109/L with <25% neutrophils. In noninflammatory arthritis, the leukocyte count can rise to up to 2 × 109/L with <25% neutrophils.

D) INCORRECT:

Positively birefringent crystals in the synovial fluid suggest acute calcium pyrophosphate (CPP) crystal arthritis (previously known as pseudogout); although a patient may present with both septic arthritis and acute CPP crystal arthritis, this would be very rare.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no single cutoff for the synovial-fluid leukocyte count in the diagnosis of septic arthritis; however, the higher the count, the higher the likelihood of this condition in the right clinical context: Leukocyte counts > 100 × 109/L have a likelihood ratio of 28 for septic arthritis, whereas those < 25 × 109/L have a likelihood ratio of only 0.32.

questions.text: You are seeing a 59-year-old man in the emergency department with a 4-day history of severe left knee pain. He had a total knee arthroplasty of the left knee 4 months ago. His medical history includes hypertension and osteoarthritis. His current medications are glucosamine, amlodipine, and meloxicam. His temperature is 38.1°C, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 118/71 mm Hg. On examination, his left knee joint is tender and swollen, with limited range of motion due to pain. Synovial fluid analysis confirms septic arthritis, and the prosthesis is removed. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Staphylococcus epidermidis has the ability to form a biofilm. It can therefore grow on the surface of foreign material such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic cardiac valves, IV catheters, and pacemakers. The patient underwent an arthroplasty in his left knee 4 months ago and is now presenting with septic arthritis, which makes a foreign body infection very likely. S. epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic infections 3–12 months after surgery.

If the patient's infection had developed either < 3 months or > 12 months after surgery, Staphylococcus aureus would be the most likely causal organism.

Key learning point: Staphylococcus epidermidis is the most common cause of prosthetic joint infection occurring 3–12 months after implantation due to its ability to form biofilms on foreign material.

B) INCORRECT:

Escherichia coli is a possible cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. However, this patient has no history of immunodeficiency, making this answer unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a common cause of septic arthritis in immunodeficient patients. This patient has no history of conditions that would increase the risk of P. aeruginosa infection (e.g., malignancy, HIV infection, diabetes mellitus), which makes this answer unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Streptococcus agalactiae, a group B Streptococcus, does not commonly cause septic arthritis, making this answer unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of septic arthritis. However, patients with joint infection due to S. aureus are usually acutely ill with high fever, chills, and onset of symptoms within 3 months after arthroplasty (when the infection is acquired during implantation) or after 12 months from surgery (due to hematogenous infection). Given the fact that this patient presents 4 months after surgery, an infection with a less virulent pathogen is more likely.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation with a tender and swollen knee and low-grade fever is consistent with septic arthritis. His history of arthroplasty makes a bacterial prosthetic joint infection most likely, even 4 months after the operation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 51-year-old woman in the emergency department with a 1-day history of severe left knee pain. She recently began jogging several times per week. Her medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, managed with metformin and chlorothiazide. Her temperature is 38.5°C. The left knee is swollen, tender to palpation, and has a significantly impaired range of motion. On examination, there is a 1.5-cm painless ulcer on the plantar surface of her left foot. Which one of the following is most likely to help establish the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Arthrocentesis is the best next step in this patient with typical symptoms of septic arthritis, including fever, joint pain, and restricted range of motion. The knee is a commonly affected joint in septic arthritis, which is most commonly caused by hematogenous spread of bacteria (most commonly Staphylococcus aureus) from a distant wound site, such as an infected diabetic ulcer. Typical findings in arthrocentesis include a synovial fluid WBC count of over 50,000/μL with dominance of polymorphonuclear cells (PMN).

Following arthrocentesis and culture, empiric treatment for septic arthritis (parenteral antibiotics based on the Gram stain) should be initiated immediately to avoid severe joint damage, which is primarily caused by bacterial invasion of cartilage.

Key learning point: Arthrocentesis is the most important diagnostic test for suspected septic arthritis, as it allows for definitive identification of infection through synovial fluid analysis and culture.
Image Description:

Synovial fluid predominantly shows neutrophils.

B) INCORRECT:

Serum uric acid levels can be elevated in patients with gout. This patient's use of thiazide diuretics and diabetes mellitus put her at increased risk for gout. She also has some typical findings of an acute gout attack such as joint pain, swelling, and restricted range of motion. However, the presence of a distant wound site makes another diagnosis more likely. Furthermore, serum uric acid levels can be normal, raised, or even low during an acute gouty attack. Therefore, measuring serum uric acid levels may not be useful in diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

MRI of the knee is the imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of occult meniscal tears, which can arise from knee injuries or degenerative processes. Although there is no history of recent knee trauma, this patient recently started exercising and she could have suffered a previously undiagnosed meniscal tear. However, meniscal tears cannot explain this patient's fever, and in the presence of a distant wound site, another diagnosis would be more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid factor test can aid in the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which can affect the knee joints. However, it would typically present with symmetrical polyarthritis of the finger and wrist joints, morning stiffness, and constitutional symptoms, which this patient does not have.

E) INCORRECT:

HLA-B27 can aid in the diagnosis of reactive arthritis, which usually presents with fever and lower extremity joint pain. However, it typically presents as asymmetrical polyarthritis that is often combined with sacroiliitis and extra‑articular symptoms (e.g., conjunctivitis or anterior uveitis), which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this patient lacks symptoms of a preceding infection such as diarrhea or dysuria.
questions.hint: Permanent joint destruction is a dreaded complication of this patient's condition.

questions.text: You are seeing a 42-year-old man with a history of hypertension and bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees who presents with severe pain and swelling of his left knee that began 3 days ago. He reports chills and decreased energy. He denies any recent trauma to the knee. On examination, his left knee is hot, erythematous, with a significant joint effusion and decreased range of motion. Knee joint aspirate shows a leukocyte count of 90 × 109/L with 95% neutrophils. Gram stain of the joint fluid reveals gram-positive cocci. Which one of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

B) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

C) INCORRECT:

Enterococcus faecalis, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Streptococcus viridans are gram-positive cocci, but they are less likely to cause acute septic arthritis in otherwise healthy adults who have no immunocompromising conditions. (Streptococci account for approximately 20% of cases of septic arthritis.)

D) INCORRECT:

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active adults, but the organism is a gram-negative coccus that is infrequently seen on Gram stain.

E) CORRECT:

Acute septic arthritis typically manifests as pain and swelling of the affected joint, with physical examination showing inflammatory changes and joint aspirate showing an elevated leukocyte count. Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent causative agent in adults (isolated in 37% to 56% of cases). Risk factors for septic arthritis include extremes of age (being very old or very young), immunosuppressive disease, recent joint surgery, and underlying joint disease, such as rheumatoid arthritis or osteoarthritis. Management of acute septic arthritis includes targeted antimicrobial therapy and either joint fluid aspiration or arthrotomy with debridement.

Key learning point: The most common agent causing acute septic arthritis with gram-positive cocci seen on Gram stain of the joint fluid is Staphylococcus aureus.
questions.hint: This patient's joint pain, restricted range of motion of the affected joint, history of bilateral osteoarthritis of the knees, in combination with synovial fluid findings, raise suspicion for septic arthritis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-year-old boy who presents with a 3-day history of fever and a right-sided limp. His mother reports that he had a cough and rhinitis for several days prior to the onset of fever. There is no history of trauma. He refuses to bear weight on his right leg and becomes irritable when his right lower limb is palpated. His temperature is 40.5°C and pulse is 130/min. Examination reveals that his right knee is swollen, red, and warm with an effusion. There is limited range of motion in flexion and extension of the knee. These findings are most consistent with which one of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is a noninfectious syndrome that involves avascular necrosis of the hip and affects children 4 to 10 years of age. It manifests with hip pain and limp.

B) CORRECT:

Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis. Bacterial infection of the hip is a surgical emergency, because a delay in drainage can lead to aseptic necrosis of the hip and long-term complications.

Septic arthritis in children usually results from hematogenous spread from a focus of infection elsewhere in the body; upper respiratory infections precede septic arthritis in up to 50% of cases. Joint pain is usually severe, and the infected joint and periarticular tissues are swollen, hot, and sometimes erythematous. Passive and active motion of the joint is severely, often completely, restricted. Knees, hips, ankles, and elbows account for 90% of infected joints in children.

Even with early and appropriate antibiotic treatment, permanent joint damage is common, and therefore septic arthritis should always be ruled out and even treated empirically when clinical suspicion is high. Staphylococcus aureus and nongroup A and B streptococci are the most common causes of septic arthritis in children overall, but other organisms are particularly prevalent in certain age groups, such as Kingella kingae in young children and Neisseria gonorrhoeae in neonates and adolescents. Consideration of concomitant osteomyelitis is important in cases of septic arthritis, particularly in young children, as the presence of bone infection has implications for antibiotic duration.

Key learning point: Fever and limp with associated arthritis should always raise suspicion for septic arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute rheumatic fever can cause fever and arthritis, especially after a recent pharyngeal infection with Streptococcus pyogenes. However, it is rare in the United States in children younger than 4 years of age, and the latency period between streptococcal infection and rheumatic fever is typically 2 to 3 weeks. The diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever can be established by performing a test for recent streptococcal infection as well as evaluation for the presence of Jones criteria.

D) INCORRECT:

Transient synovitis often follows a recent upper respiratory infection but does not usually cause a fever. It is among the most common causes of hip pain in young children; some children may report medial thigh or knee pain.

E) INCORRECT:

Kawasaki disease is a multisystemic febrile illness; arthritis is an unusual manifestation and is not one of the diagnostic criteria. Furthermore, other than fever, this child has none of the other criteria needed to make a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease.
questions.hint: Arthrocentesis with synovial fluid analysis is the diagnostic modality of choice for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of right knee swelling and left ankle pain. He reports mild conjunctival irritation and dysuria but denies fever. Three weeks ago, he had self-limiting diarrhea lasting 5 days. Physical examination shows asymmetrical joint swelling affecting the knee and ankle with decreased range of motion. Laboratory studies show ESR 45 mm/hr, CRP 12 mg/L, and synovial fluid analysis shows watery yellow fluid with WBC 15,000/mm³ (90% neutrophils) and a negative Gram stain on microscopy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Joint aspiration and drainage would be the treatment for septic arthritis with purulent material requiring evacuation. This patient's synovial fluid is watery and shows a WBC count in the inflammatory range (> 2,000 WBC/mm³) and less than the typical septic range (> 50,000 WBC/mm³). The negative Gram stain also makes sterile inflammation a stronger possibility, even though it does not rule out septic arthritis on its own.
